reviewText:
Best anger management therapy that you will find.

10/10 Will play forever.

All right, since some people found this review helpful I'll try to make a decent review:

Doom is, as you may already know, a very fast-paced FPS with not much story to tell, but with a lot of other things that can, and will appeal people looking for simple but by no means easy gameplay. I recomend this game to any person who likes FPS games. I'll try to cover some points of interest:

Graphics: Of course, being this game 22 years old (as of this review) the graphics are really dated for a PC game; having a resolution of 320x200 (IIRC), and 256 colors, you can clearly see 'big' pixels. Even then, the game keeps a good atmosphere for the most part. So if you're picky about graphics, maybe the atmosphere created by the game will keep you sane while playing.

Sound: The same as the last point; it's old. Even then, the sounds fit, so enemies growls and scratches evoke a sense of danger around the corner. And the music... oh man, the music fits so well in the game. Fast action along with metal (for the most part) music is a good combination!

Gameplay: Now this is the core of this game. This is the reason why I keep coming back to it. Just like the basics of any FPS game, you get a set of weapons, a bunch of enemies and then you empty your shells, cells, batteries, etc. upon them. Doom is just this. There's only you and demons. You have 8 (9 in Doom II) weapons to kill them, and the action is faster than most FPS out there. Walk, strafe, fire, dodge. Of course it's not only a corridor or halls full of enemies you have to dispatch, there are puzzles, with keys (or skulls) and switches or trap floors. It's not only just killing, mind you!

Story: The only story you get is the one that came in the manual, but you can find it easily online. But in short; you're a (unnamed) marine, working at the Union Aerospace Corporation in mars, when portals bring out demons from hell and the rest of the people get slaughtered, so it's up to you to stop the demon invasion. How the story is coming along is told in short 'intermision' screens at the end of every chapter.

Replay Value: Yes. Just yes. Why else would I keep on coming back to doom if this game didn't have any sort of replay value? And if the game bores you, you have the mods. You won't have enough time in your life to play all the community content that has been created for this game. So look for them! There are a lot of websites with links to these mods!

Controls: Now, the native controls of Doom will probably feel uncomfortable for most people nowadays. You can only walk, turn, strafe, use and shoot (and of course run). Strafe is kind of tricky the first time, and you can even move with the mouse (not turn). You can only look to the sides, and shooting an enemy above you is done by autoaim.

Try this game with another sourceport that is not Dosbox if you want full support for mods and/or want to change many more options for graphics, sound, and controls (most sourceports makes doom controls more akin to today FPS). There are many different ones for each taste, too.

TLDR: Game is astounding, simple gameplay, enough challenge, and you have countless of mods to keep on playing forever, like I do.

reviewText:
Ahhh DOOM... Talk to any gamer who grew up in the 90's and they will surely recount fond memories of all the good times they had playing id Software's original magnum opus. Wolfenstein 3D may have pioneered the First-Person Shooter genre, however it was DOOM that really brought it into the spotlight. Originally released in December of '93, DOOM would later be re-released with an extra episode, re-labled as The Ultimate DOOM.

At first glance The Ultimate DOOM may seem a simple affair by today's standards, what with it's deceptively simple gameplay. However looks can be deceiving, as the DOOM series is know for it's twisted mazelike corridors. Gamers who are used to the linear games of today could find themselves lost for hours in a level, searching for the next keycard. In the era that DOOM was released the length of a game was provided by actual gameplay, and not by artificially padding the experience with cutscenes every 3 seconds.

The gameplay in DOOM is a satisfying affair in which players must dispatch hoards of hell's minions while searching out colored keycards to unlock the various doors that block their path, all the while searching out the games myriad secrets, which usually results in a serious upgrade of firepower. And you'll need that firepower, as the baddies keep getting bigger and more badass as you go. The best gun in the game, which can be seen below as the player faces off against the Spider Mastermind, is the BFG 9000, AKA the Big Freakin' Gun. It launches a big green ball of energy that will frag the living hell out of anything in it's path.

Another thing DOOM popularized was the fine art of Deathmatch. Players could use their brand new dialup modems to engage each other in bloody warfare, where victory was determined by how many times you could reduce your foes to a pile of chunky kibble. Since DOOM's inception of Deathmatch it has become a staple of nearly every game in the FPS genre since. The Ultimate DOOM is truely a genre-defining game, and if you have never tried it you owe it to yourself as an FPS fan to give it a try.

reviewText:
The Ultimate Doom is a re-release of the original Doom and features an entirely new episode on top of the three that were previously available. In addition it know supports modern controls of “wasd” and mouse support, though you are still unable to look vertically like in the original. It is the spiritual successor to Wolfenstein 3D and is credited for popularizing the FPS genre. This time around you'll be facing the forces of hell instead of Nazis and their dogs. The tone for this game is much more morbid and disturbing than it's predecessor's endless blue and gray hallways. You'll often times find your fellow space marines dead or still alive and twitching if they are unlucky. Rooms can now be pitch black and you will have to slowly inch yourself forward, toward your objective in fear of being caught by surprise in what may be lurking in the darkness. Without the awesome metal soundtrack blasting in the background, Doom would be pretty unsettling at times.

Unlike Wolf 3D this now has floor and ceiling textures, which make for far more immersive environments. But there is no mistaking that these are indeed graphics from 1993 and what may have seemed impressive back then like vertical environments , flickering lights and gore, are typical these days and will no longer impress anyone. Where Doom stands the test of time is in it's gameplay and level design. It's rapid movement and maze like environments to explore are likely to be strange to those that have not experienced an old school FPS, but they do insure ensure fluid, exciting gameplay and replay value as you seek the hidden goodies like extra levels that you didn't find your first time through. There is no iron-sites or reloading here, instead we have an auto-aim feature that will see to it that you hit an enemy if you are facing it, though it does freak out at times when fighting on a vertical plane.

Starting off you will be able to choose any of the four episodes to start off with though I highly recommend starting from the first as to allow the game to introduce weapons, enemies and game mechanics. There is no story to keep track of but if you are to start on the later episodes without a firm understanding of the weapons and how to fight demons, you will surely fail. Then you will chose from five difficulty modes that change the type and amount of enemies you will encounter throughout the level. And as soon as you pick one it's straight to the game. No story and no explanation, just you and a pistol. You will soon come across the body of a deceased marine that is facing the door and you will be able to hear a monstrous gurgle beyond the door. Meeting an enemy for the first time is always an epic encounter and you will not have any time to gawk at it. You just have to try to gun it down and hope that strange creatures goes down before you do. It is scenarios like these, that make me highly advise starting on anything other than episode 1 your first time around.

Unlike Wolf 3D most enemies are not hit-scan and usually have projectiles that you can avoid if you react fast enough. It makes it feel like a really deadly match of dodge-ball as you zoom across the levels, avoiding multiple projectiles and gunning down all in your path without a single scratch. If you do get hit your characters face shown in the bottom of the screen will get bloodier and bloodier, until the point that he is near death and in tears. This is one of the small details that frightened me as a child, seeing your badass space marine bloody and in tears is something still not seen in many games and reminds you that our hero is indeed human, even if it has no gameplay effect and he still moves faster than Sonic the Hedgehog. If you are injured you will have to find a medkit to restore your health and if you are lucky you may also find some armor to absorb some damage. There are also power-ups hidden across the level like a Berserk orb that causes your fists to cause much more damage for the entire level. Some are necessary to progress though like the Hazmat suit that allows you to walk on lava and other hazards.

Thinking outside the box will sometimes be necessary  in your search of the three keycards you will need to escape the level. Like in E4M6 there is a teleporter that will teleport you to different locations depending on which side you step on it, it may seem like a simple puzzle but you have to run across lava to access that tiny teleporter. If you quick-save in certain locations like that, it is possible that you will doom yourself to death if you already used the hazmat suit and don't have enough health to run across that much lava. In that case hopefully you had another save or you will be put on the start of that level with just a pistol. Most of these instances are found in Episode 4 as they tried their hand at some light “platforming”  but with Doom's inability to look up and down, crumby auto-aiming if you are not on the same plane as enemy and lightning fast movement, tiny platforms that you must traverse are quite an annoyance.  It is also the first Episode in which you ever have to use the run key and it overall felt like the weakest link out of all Episodes.

Weapons are usually hidden throughout the levels giving you yet another reason to explore areas carefully. These can range from chainguns, rocket launchers and the legendary BFG-9000. You will have to find ammo for them as well and as you can tell by now scavenging for supplies is very important. Ammo backpacks are very will hidden but if you find one they will allow you to carry more ammo at once. The zombie grunts will drop either pistol or shotgun ammo but neither of these will do you much good against the more powerful demons. Demons are very aggressive and this can be used to your advantage. If a demon accidentally hits another demon they will fight to the death and you can use this distraction to either sneak away or to easily take down the victor of that skirmish. They are quite varied and have different methods of attacking, so dealing with each one is requires different method and learning how to identify your largest threat is a must. Confidence can also lead to your downfall, you may think you have taken care of every enemy in the level and spot a powerful gun in the open, only to be ambushed by demons that were hiding. Be it creepy noises, distant groans or evil looking background, this game does a great job at making sure you rarely feel safe.

I did have a problem with the Steam version of this game having distorted colors and flickering. I was  able to fix it by following this guide.  With that said, this game should last you around 6 hours but it does have decent replay value and plenty of secrets to find. After each level it tells you the percent of enemies killed, percent of secrets and the time it took you to complete, which may lead you to want to do better. Most levels before Episode 4 have a unique song that plays throughout that further helps differentiate the levels from one another. The environments are mostly brown and gray, so they start to look the same after a while but thanks to excellent level design, no two levels feel the same. If you ever get lost, there is an in game map for each level, though it can be confusing when levels have some verticality to them. While Doom's graphics are now laughable and can be run on most consoles or even your local ATM, it's now extinct form of gameplay is still as fun as ever.  I wouldn't recommend Doom to those that need a plot to drive them forward or to those that hate exploring. Those that don't mind the lack of narrative and want fast, unrelenting gameplay, are more likely than not going to have a heck of a time with this title. While it is starting to show it's age, good old grandpa Doom still has plenty of fight left in him.

reviewText: Doom is a household name for good reason. It's a game that brought the gaming industry to it's knees and changed the landscape of video games and software forever. Doom resulted in the widespread adoption of the Windows operating system and later the creation of DirectX. Doom popularized the first person shooter, which is now one of the most popular video game genres. It directly lead to custom maps, modifications, source code releases and online multiplayer being a thing.\n\nMost importantly, Doom is a symbol. It's a symbol of everything good in video games. It is the product of nights spent computer programming, playing Dungeons and Dragons and wishing fervently to make, That game". That game you fantasize about playing in the back of your mind
date: that game you think people will judge you for playing
recommended: that game that you play 20 years later and find it's still as fresh as the day you bought it.\n\nDoom; "That game"."

reviewText:
Doom: One of the few first person shooters to make you feel smart after mindlessly killing hordes of zombie aliens.

When you first start playing doom you are simply given a pistol and a room from which you will start your adventure. Depending on the difficulty you selected, you might face enemies right off the bat, but for the sake of the review I will base my experience on the “I’m too young to die!” difficulty (very-easy in layman’s terms). Playing through the game on such a level allows me to casually stroll through the levels, while appreciating the atmosphere provided.

The first level set on Phobos, one of Mars’ moons, where aliens have come through the portals and killed all of your friends. Every single one. You’re the only man left and you’ve made it your duty to take revenge on every last living thing on this moon. You soon find out the scientists working on the moons were working with portals and attempted to link Phobos and Deimos together. One thing lead to another and the events of this game slowly unraveled from there.
It’s time to delve into the designs of these levels.

These new stages in the game are well thought out, with new weapons before tougher enemies, and secrets that reward you with powerful weapons (Ones that you wouldn’t normally get for a few more levels). Key cards are used to open doors with the corresponding color, and are normally accompanied by health and ammo, because it sure as hell wasn’t easy to get to them. Some maps use dark rooms to set the tone, which work to the games advantage, especially when you’re facing those invisible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s which can take huge chunks of health with one swipe. Some maps use maze like configuration to add a level of difficulty, and you can bet that each dead end is guarded by an enemy.

Each level set is finished with a challenging, yet rewarding boss battle. Again, the level design was superb for setting the tone. A long hallway which provided ammo, health, and armor, told me that I was in for a treat when I entered the elevator. For the difficulty I chose, I was given two CyberDemons to face, which were new to me, allowing me to see how they attacked and how much ammo I would be using to kill each one. After defeating the glorified demon at the end of that trek, it truly feels like the levels you played through were just a training match before the final showdown.

To sum it all up, you should really buy this fantastic, innovative game. The enemies are challenging, the boss battles are rewarding, the setting of the game is revolutionary, and the levels are creative and enjoyable. The game has great replay ability, and finding new secrets with each play through enhances the game play even further. For the $5 price tag, you are getting a game that will keep you occupied for hours to come.

reviewText:
Kids, let me tell you about an ego shooter of yesteryear. One of THE ego shooters of yesteryear, to be precise: DOOM!

It may not look like much nowadays, but it's still a fantastic, fast-paced shooter with (rather) open maps, great soundtrack (seriously, I love it!) and lots of hellspawn to take apart!
And not only is it still a great game, but it still has an active modding community. If that's not amazing, then I don't know what is!

I've played through the game with the Brutal Doom mod, btw., which makes the game EVEN better! Seriously, give it a spin!

reviewText:
If you don't know what the hell Doom is, then you are clearly not very familiar with First Person Shooters, or possibly gaming. Doom wasn't any normal First Person Shooter - it was THE FPS. The FPS that increased the potential of 3D game design, what the genre could do and made the genre popular. Wolvenstein may have given birth to the genre, but the genre wouldn't be as popular as it is now if it wasn't for this legendary game.

... but the question is, does it still hold up? Let's get on with the review!!

The story is as simple as early 90s games go but there is also a backstory to the player character as well - after our hero has disobeyed orders from a commanding officer to fire upon civilians and decide to stop him instead, he has been sent to work at a military base on Mars, which behaves as a Security post for a Multi-Planetary Conglomerate called the Union Aerospace Corporation (abbreviated UAC). The UAC itself is currently testing teleportation between Mars and it's two moons Phobos and Deimos in secrecy. Nothing special was really happening there... until one day, all hell quite literally breaks loose. The base on Deimos completely disappears off the face of the moon and a frantic distress signal was sent to Mars from Phobos, stating that something... evil" has poured out of the teleportation gateway. Our hero (called Doomguy by the community

reviewText:
One simple word, one simple game, the absolute best FPS on the planet: DOOM

Straight out of 1993, Doom was a game made simply because the group of 20 something year olds wanted to make it. It's a game where design splashes with creativity, something you don't find in almost any modern game today.

The game is simple. Get to the end of each stage. That's it. You also need to kill the literal thousands of demon hellspawn along the way so don't forget about them either. The monsters range from simple zombie soldiers to demonic goats that shoot rockets at you. The games monsters all revolve around the notion of avoiding projectiles, or hitscans.

The maps are designed with absolute love and attention. Each episode was made usually by one person, and you really can feel that distinction when you play them. Some maps were mazes, some maps were collosiums, some maps used more of a certain ammo type, thus limiting your approach, but most of all, the designs of the maps are interesting and fun to play.

Doom is a testament to the 90's, and a bit to the 80's. The loud metal induced music, the overall design, the action and horror of films such as Aliens. Everything is combined in such a perfect, uniform way that nothing feels out of place.

Doom is in a nutshell, just a game that feels right to play. Not a single aspect about the game feels wrong at all, and thats something you never see anymore in games. The attention to detail and gameplay is absolutely amazing.

There is not one single game I've ever played that did everything as perfect as Doom did. The monsters, the maps, the design, the gameplay, the mechanics, the feel, is all so perfect, that you really need this in your library.

Being a game from 1993, the game runs on DOSBOX. If you don't like that, there's plenty of source ports out there, like ZDoom, Zandronum (which focuses on multiplayer as well), and for a faithfull recration of the game, Chocolate Doom. There's also literally millions upon millions of custom content for the game as well. Some wads I could reccomend include classics such as Alien Vendetta, Memento Mori 1 and 2, Hell Revealed and some new ones such as Back to Saturn X, Doom the way id Did, Doom 2 the way id Did, ZDoom community map project 1 and 2, and the PSX Total Conversion.

Doom is a game I will always see myself coming back to, even when we are in 2047 playing games on a display device in our brains.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Brutal Doom Mention: On the topic of this flamboyent mess of a mod, I'll give my honest opinions on it, because as an avid Doomer from the earliest days, I suppose I should explain my self in detail.
Brutal Doom is a mod for Doom that throws in absolute rediculous amounts of gore and changes the enemies behavior entirely. Shots deal damage based on location on the body. For example, shooting an imp in the head kills it instantly. You have iron sights on some weapons and you have to reload your clips (this can be turned off with mutators" that can be downloaded individually)

Now all of this sounds like the perfect way to modernize Doom right? Wrong. Brutal Doom completely destroys the balance of the original Doom maps

reviewText: I remember vaguely my brother playing this game when I was real young (and by real young around 5-7 years old XD), and that is the majority of the reason I got this game. I wanted to experience what he experienced as a gamer and I always liked watching him playing video games(except I couldn't watch this one because it was so gorey, but managed to peek many times). To me, this is the birth of the FPS genre and it's great to see how much it has evolved over the years. It's also great to be able to go back into the past to play this game. I love how there are a variety of difficulties, from those who are very newbish to the very hardcore gamer. This is an arcade-like game where you just gotta kill everything around you and pass the level. Secrets? Optional. Simplicity? Yes. A gem in time that will always live on? Very, very likely.

reviewText: Innovative, revolutionary, groundbreaking, just many of the words to describe Doom. Doom really seems like one of those games that you should play at least once before you die. While the original controls are very clunky in this day and age this problem is easily remedied with source ports like GZDoom and Zandronum that allow a modern mouse and keyboard setup. What is on offer is a very challenging game with  fantastic action, intricate level design, and really ignited and paved the way for shooters to come. It seems that every shooter has something that traces back to Doom. When you finish the game there's quite literally thousands of mods to try out. Personally I also like to think of this game as a rite of passage for any FPS fan

reviewText:
Ah, Doom. I'm such a big fan of this Hellish series, I've been playing for years already. And It never gets old. Doom Is one of my most favorite games of all time, I'm not a big fan of Doom 2 though. I'm just too use to this classic here. You play as a Space Marine or Doomguy, as you run and gun your way out of Hellish Demons and Zombies. A classic game from 1993, Doom was one of the goriest games In It's time. And you would headbang to the heavy metal music while gunning down Zombiemen and Imps. This version here Is The Uiltmate Doom, where It Includes a new fourth episode titled Thy Flesh Consumed.

Episodes:
Knee-Deep In The Dead: This Is my favorite, well. I'm sure It's everybody's favorite. This Is where It all begins, the Hellish rampage starts.
The Shores of Hell: My least favorite, this took me a while to complete. But I know my ways through this episode.
Inferno: The final episode, and the best out of all the episodes, Is where you finally confront The Spider-Mastermind. And This Is my most favorite episode.
Thy Flesh Consumed: I've not played this one yet, but I'll give It a try one of these days.

I highly recommend this game to new and old school gamers, or for those who never played FPS before. I completely rate this classic a 10/10. I know It's overated folks, but a game like Doom deserves It. For making the FPS Genre so popular today.

The game is great, without any doubt. The amount of hours I wasted in my childhood playing DOOM games is absolutely insane and would be enough for a second life. So the game is a rock solid 10 out of 10, no questions asked. And if you have not played it yet, DO IT!

But not this Steam version, which is kind of unplayable due to bad pre-configuration or the fact that Steam, otherwise than GOG, just throws old games like these barely playable on the market.

Tip: Google and install GZDoom, ZDoom or any other source port, copy the *.wad files from your Steam installation to that folder, add some BrutalDoom / Project Brutality mod to it and you're good to go.

This way you'll probably waaaay more fun, believe me :)

Edit: I've seen that the first two DOOMs are now available on GOG (Good Old Games). I bought them there (because I hate DRM as much as I love GOG) and guess what? They run. I installed the first two DOOMs and they just work like they should. That's the reason why Steam isn't really the best adress for old games like these ones. They don't try to polish them (in terms of make them playable") or try to uphold the functionality like GOG does. Besides that

reviewText:
Long story short: One of the oldest, yet still engaging, shooters of the '90s. It's not only a graphical spectacle, it's also tightly desgined around skill-based encounters, while offering enough variety for a good six to eight hour game length, plus a butt-load of mods online. For those buying the Steam version, check the community guides to help you set it up for a more optimal introduction to the game.
DISCLAIMER: While no demo is available on Steam, Googling Doom Shareware should lead you to the free version of the game, which contains only the first episode to give you a decently lengthed snippet of what the game is like.

After the release of this game, every first-person shooter for the next few years were referred to as Doom clones purely because this game right here did everything so well. Simply, Doom is one of the tightest games you'll ever play. Guaranteed. While taking place on abandoned research bases on Mars, and eventually into Hell itself, the game's spooky vibes do not correspond with horror as much as balls-to-the-wall action. However, most of its spectacle is due to the fact that it was the first of its kind: many FPS games thereafter utilised Doom's formula, to varying and even greater degrees of success. To fully enjoy this game, try to forget all that you already know about games and take this game from its rawest form.

Let's get it out of the way: Doom had a magnificent engine. It needed a decent rig to get working at the time, but man did it get 3D working so well. The engine allowed floors to be rendered at multiple heights, any angle conceivable, and all textured, allowing for some magnificent looking locales. Lighting also worked to build atmosphere and contrast between levels. And, enemy sprites were very detailed, and allowed them to be animated during attacks and hit animations from all angles. Briefly, it was visuals like no other.

The sound is a little bit uninspired however. Some sound effects are public domain (the imp sound in particular), and may sound familiar. The music also takes a few, let's say, subtle hints from metal and grunge music of the '80s and '90s. However, all of it fits towards the demonic tone that the game goes for.

The game consists of four episodes, each taking place in different locations. The aesthetics of each place vary a bit too, and the general design changes a bit too. Each episode introduces new things, allowing the player to constantly learn techniques and skills in tackling enemies. Every level also has a bunch of secrets (including some secret levels), which is a great way to give incentives to explore the levels.

The highlight of the game in my opinion are the enemies. The weakest enemies, the Former Human and Sergeants, are also the only enemies that hitscan (attack with an instant bullet-like attack). Every other enemy uses projectiles of varying damage, speeds, and colours, and they're all avoidable. Doom's gameplay consists of dodging enemy attacks, prioritising targets, navigating and using the map to your advantage, and conserving ammo and attacking efficiently. It leads you in, gives you enough time to evaluate the threat, and skillfully execute a plan to either avoid or take out hoards of enemies. And it does this organically by not removing control or agency from the player.

The weapons also have a huge layer of depth. Besides the slow starting pistol, every weapon you find doesn't out-right replace other weapons you get. Rather, each weapon has its own benefits and weaknesses. For example, the shotgun can deal large chunks of damage in successive blasts, but it's not as efficient or quick as other weapons, whereas the plasma rifle fires huge balls of energy at enemies, but have a delay between shooting and the projectile hitting the target. Each weapon works well against certain enemies, and the player organically learns these as the game goes on, rather than being down-right told about it.

The levels are also designed to give varying degrees of challenge between encounters. While enemies are littered around the levels, generally you are presented rooms, and you have to solve problems with them, usually a locked door. This involves crossing the level sometimes, which may also have unlocked a hidden swarm of enemies. Fighting enemies in large open rooms, and fighting in closed in corridors provide different skill-sets.

Doom also was pretty revolutionary for its modding system. The main game acts as a base archive, and custom levels or mods (in WAD files) replace or expand this content. It's simple to distribute, and resources such as the Idgames archive are being updated to this day with new and amazing content. I recommend the Brutal Doom mod, which replaces the weapons and enemy behaviors in a...ludicrous manner.

Doom is one of the greatest games of all time, not because of its graphical leaps, but because it was also a tight as heck game. If you're going to grab the classic bundle, more mods are created for the sequel, Doom II, which expands on this game with crazier enemies and levels. The Doom 3 BFG Edition also includes this game and the sequel as well (not as Steam products, but within the title itself), and remains the best bundle for this game. The price point is a bit high for the game's age, but it's quality is worth every bit of it.

RATING: 3 UP, 0 DOWNMy up/down rating system tries to differentiate between games that are mediocre (less ups and downs total), and games that are interesting but flawed (more ups and downs totals). Ups relate to how much good a game has, and downs are how much bad a game has.

[/table]            0 UPs        1 UPs        2 UPs        3 UPs                Not worth playing, skip it        Alright, play it if you're into the genre        Very good, play it if you're looking for something worth trying        One to go down in history, a must have for everyone[/table]            0 DOWNs        1 DOWNs        2 DOWNs        3 DOWNs                Nothing detrimental in the game        A few things wrong, but doesn't ruin it        Kind-of broken or aggravating, you may not be able to put up with it        Very, very broken, a lesson on what not to do

reviewText:
First of all, this game has terrible outdated graphics, an 8-bit soundtrack, you can't jump, and you can't look up or down.

And I love this game for all those things I mentioned above. It's a classic that popularized the FPS genre, and with a fourth Doom on the way, I figured I should just buy this game to understand the hype. I love video games and have played some pretty old games before, like Jedi Power Battles, Mortal Kombat Trilogy, Pac Man, and Galaga.  Even with all of the advanced graphics and detailed combat we have in today's games, I still go back to the old days from time to time and enjoy the classics.

So how did I not discover Doom back then? Never heard of it until a few years later. I'm not part of the older gaming generation, which is why. So I decided to try it. It's simple, but it's incredibly fun and it's worth playing if you love the classics.

This is a game that became the subject of controversy regarding video game violence, which is a subject that has been discussed to death, even to this day (sigh). To be honest with you, violent video games are meant to be played by responsible individuals who can differentiate fiction from reality, although the media hasn't realized that yet..

But the controversy of this game also contributed to its popularity. Sure, the violence seems like nothing compared to today's video games, but back then, this was probably one of the most violent games ever. When you combine the violence with an ominous soundtrack, you can understand why some people were shocked. With all that aside, it's still an incredible classic, regardless of the controversy, and since video games were meant for fun and nothing else, go ahead and give it a try!

reviewText:
Great memorable and revolutionary game. Doom 2 and Final Doom are great too. Must haves for anyone who likes fun.

Don't bother with the dosbox setup, as its pretty ♥♥♥♥. Get source ports like:
-Chocolate Doom
Highly Accurate to the original DOS executable (bugs and limits included), while being a windows based port. Great for a more authentic experience without the hassle of Dosbox.
-PrBoom+
Raises the static limitations of the original, options for Modern screen resolutions/OpenGL, and  includes support for the boom/MBF formats. Most maps for these formats are still generally traditional with the gameplay. Compatibility levels for different versions of doom make it good for demo playback.
-ZDoom/GZDoom
Numerous advanced features, and supports Heretic, Hexen, and Strife.  Mouselook and Jumping/Crouching are possible in this engine. Most mods for this tend to be less traditional with the gameplay, and often change things up a lot more. Great for those who want to play gameplay mods, and certain partial/total conversions.
-Odamex/Zandronum
These are basically multiplayer source ports with online capabilities. Odamex for a more traditional approach, and Zandronum for a more modern approach.

reviewText:
A lot can be said about Doom. It started a fascination with first-person shooters that still lingers to this day. It spurred a rise in violent video games that eventually necessitated a ratings system. It pushed the limitations of 3D graphics to breathtaking highs in 1993. It revolutionized LAN play and was the catalyst for internet TCP/IP play.

But by now, you probably all know that. Doom is such a big name that it was even made into a (rather mediocre) film in 2005. It's become part of pop culture and the media conciousness. To try and sum it up is pointless.

What you really want to know is whether or not grabbing the Steam version is worth it. In it's default state, I would say no. The copies on Steam are emulated through DOSBox, which kind of sucks. The games run fine and all, but they have low resolution, choppy sound and some obtuse key bindings.

Still, ID Software also pioneered a new file format when they released Doom; the WAD file. Since this version is basically the same one from the 1995 re-release, it has the WAD file that can be extracted to any numerous source ports available. There is even a method of making ZDoom (one of the most popular ports) work with the Steam overlay.

For that reason, if you don't already own Doom, then go ahead and grab it on Steam. $15 is a great price for 2 classic games and some expansion packs. It doesn't hurt that the fundamental design of Doom is timeless. Even if you have played it before, it remains addictive and ingenius all these years later.

If anything, I think I'll be playing this until I die. I may go years without touching a single WAD, but when the itch comes, I always stick around for a long while. Those source ports can also get you online multiplayer (along with a host of other enhancements")
date: so you really cannot go wrong.\n\nAs for the game itself

The enemy design is brilliant; it conveys exactly what you need to know in seconds. Even the sound design helps with it's directional audio and individual sound bytes. This is one of the best examples of retro gaming

reviewText: The best game ever made, perhaps.  Very easy to play it on Steam using whatever sourceport or frontend you might prefer: just throw it in the game's install folder and rename your chosen executable to dosbox.  Using ZDL with gzDoom makes it super easy for me to load up the game with whatever WAD I feel like playing — including Doom II, for example, provided I copy doom2.wad into the same folder (or just direct ZDL to its location).  You can even throw in stuff like pk_anim.wad (look it up) for smoother weapon animations, which is pretty neat.  Some of you might prefer Chocolate Doom over something like gzDoom for a more pixel-accurate early '90s experience: easily done.  Maybe you want to switch over to Zandronum for some deathmatch: you got it.  Anyway, yes.  Lots of FPS games have come and gone, but Doom remains the golden standard for me.  With all the fantastic WADs available out there, it's a gift that keeps on giving.

reviewText:
Doom is a legendary FPS that came out in 1993 on PC and was ported to many other consoles, with ports of various quality. It was released by shareware model and had 3 episodes if your ordered. Later it was released as Ultimate Doom, adding the 4th episode.
Compared to other ports it has full levels and most content. PS1 and Saturn port have it combined with Doom 2 levels and have dark horror atmosphere, with N64 having it's own dark horror atmosphere and was like a new game build from scratch, with it's own levels. The only thing some ports have over PC technically got to be colored lighting. So, you don't miss much, be happy with DOS version.

As old game, we should take a look at how Steam version handles Doom. And well, Id Software once again did a horrible job with handling DOSBox.
First, it wasn't configured probably, thus it lags amazingly in full-screen mode. To fix that you have to go to game's folder and edit line at output" to "opengl" in "ultimate.conf" and "ultimatem.conf" files.
Second
date: as you launch game you will notice that you get to choose two control methods: with mouse and classic (Like real man
recommended: keyboard only!). And it uses Soundblaster device for Music instead of Midi that everybody is used to. You may think that you can use DOSBox
hoursPlayed: navigate to game's folder and launch "setup.exe" to configure stuff for yourself
voteText: but too bad! Id Software decided not to put it into Steam's version. Your only way to configure controls and music is editing "DEFAULT.CFG" and "MOUSE.CFG" files. Where you have to guess which numbers is related to what keyboard button.\n\nBut once you fixed all those issues you will finally get to play Doom. Ultimate edition

reviewText:
[EDIT: Get a sourceport, kids. I have at least 10 hours logged on ZDOOM. Better performance, better customisation and the holy autorun feature]
Having only bought this on a whim, I wasn't expecting much from Doom. After all, it's extremely primitive compared to shooters from today and is 6 years older than I am. Also, being a pioneer of a fairly complex genre, I wasn't expecting it to hold up by today's standards. However, Doom is a pleasant surprise, if you tweak it a little. The first thing I did when I turned it on was say 'What the ♥♥♥♥ are these controls?' (go get novert). Using the mouse as a joystick is almost impossible for anyone with a desk smaller than Africa. The mouse sensitivity needs to go waaaay up too. However, once you maneuver these hurdles, welcome to one of the most fast-paced, exciting FPSs there is on Steam. The pace of movement is quick and the game almost acts as a 3-D 'shmup' in later levels due to the focus on dodging and evasion. The weapons are satisfying to use and feel as if they have weight and the pixelated gore is both strangely satisfying and... y'know... gory. However, the game's age does show through many of its design quirks. Many levels are maze-like and sometimes devolve into a tedious keyhunt. Not being able to look up is also something quite hard to get used to and can be frustrating if there are invisile enemies at the top of some stairs or on elevated ground. However, despite these, the game remains extremely fun and for bonus points, once you're finished with the 4 chapters offered by the game, you can mod it to pieces
(Novert link)
https://www.doomworld.com/idgames/utils/misc/novert
( An awful lot of mods)

reviewText:
(as you may have guessed, my Steam playtime do not represent my actual hours in DOOM, which are probably in the thousands)

Still one of the best (if not the the best) shooters ever made.
Originally released in 1993, DOOM raised the bar and set the standard for the FPS genre.
Unlike many shooters of the time, DOOM has aged extremely well thanks to its great design and is still very much playable today if you can look past its dated (but still nice) graphics.
DOOM still has a very active community that continues to play the game online and make mods for it, so there's tons of content out there even after you've beat the game.

Pros:Smooth gameplay that just feels right, gunning down hordes of demons never gets old.
Legendary level design, memorable maps with tons of secrets.
Active modding/multiplayer community.
Decent graphics (albeit dated), still manages a to build a good atmosphere.
Good music, sound design is generally pretty good too.
Cons:Lacklustre port"

reviewText:
Pros
- Satisfying Gunplay. Running around like a jackrabbit as a space marine blowing the bits out of demons and zombies with like chainguns, shotguns, and plasma guns is pretty fun.
- Fun to explore levels, though I will admit it is pretty easy to get lost in some areas.
- Interesting Enemy designs
- Did I mention you're a space marine fighting demons in mars all the way through hell?

Cons
- It's a game from 1994. The graphics arent great by today's standards and you may very well not. Also first few tries running the game, it didn't mouse support, And had to look through the steam forums for a fix. You may have the same issues.

If you can stand graphics from 20 years ago and enjoy first person shooters where you obliterate armies of demons, yes you may very well like this game and pretty much the entire Doom Classic Pack. They're all pretty dope.

Note: I'd highly suggest you also try playing the mod Brutal Doom. It's a pretty dope mod, it's pretty much the same game only more difficult and with improved animation sprites and gore, as well as additional takedowns and weapons. You'd just need GZdoom to run it, and i'd actually suggest installing either Zdoom or GZdoom. They run the game better than DOSbox does, plus you've got a lot more options in the options menu.

Bought it for H-Doom

I regret

NOTHING
O
T
H
I
N
G




On a serious note:
This is the mother of shooters (next to Wolfenstein 3d being...the grandmother then?)
Who does not know Doom?
Doom pretty much made the fundament of what shooters are today. We cannot deny doom did nothing, they pretty much started with shooters back then, of course they had to test things. Why not demons? Ok, let's use demons and see how people react. And oh boy...what an impact it had, has and will still have. Let's be honest: Am I the only one who thinks E1M1's soundtrack (1. level) is pretty much the best? I am no big fan of metal, but omg, that one just makes me wanna go off an shoot demons! ...wait, that is the actual setting of the game...

What can I really say about the gameplay...well...the original controls were the arrow pads while Ctrl (I think) being the shooting button.  you have weak enemies, having a pistol or a shotgun, tankers, dealing mediocre damage but being able to take a lot of damage, and ememies, who are just strong, having the ability to fly and deal a lot of damage or just take a lot of damage and dealing a lot. Every enemy has a specific weakness, each one's different. Ofc, a BFG 9000 (i'll talk about the weapons soon) is definetly effective against everyone, but wasting that ammo for some Imps? Not useful. Ammo management is also important, so dont just foolishly spend your minigunammo. Use the shotgun or rocketlauncher, depending on the situation.
So we can say, the game requires you to think (*cough* COD *cough*)

The weapon choice is alright. In total, we have 8 weapons. The fists (pretty much your last choice you should use. DO NOT), the chainsaw (TIMBER), the shotgun (in Doom 2 we also have the double barreled shotgun), the pistol (semi-useful against weak enemies), the chaingun (your rifle" in this game
recommended: the rocketlauncher (dont need to add anything)

the ammomanagement but also the weaponvariety back then! Think of it!

We have 4 chapters with 9 levels each (if I am not mistaken). each of them isnt just like a narrow path you have to follow

reviewText:
Why do I keep coming back to Doom? It's old, blocky, and tough. It makes me jump in my chair. It fills me with dread every time I have to round a new corner. I spend half the time playing it just cowering in corners waiting for enemies to find me. It makes me feel pathetic.

I keep coming back though, because of that visceral feeling. An arcade game on the PC, realized in full 3D, which exists in its raw form within Doom. It is pure and powerful and awesome.

The fact that a pixelated game created two decades ago can still scare me pretty good, can still engage me enough to make me worry about what's around the next corner... that is a testament to the staying power of Doom.

Play Doom. It might upset you, or scare you, or freak you out. But you'll be a better person for it, having witnessed one of gaming history's finest.

reviewText: The most influential first person-shooter of all time, and likely still the greatest. Even after 21 years, no game combines the simple but challenging mix of gunplay, exploration and resource management quite as successfully. A plethora of sourceports keep the game feeling fresh; add to that the almost legendary modding community, still going strong after 2 decades, and you have a game that delivers not only tremendous entertainment value, but an entire legacy. An absolute must-have for practically any gamer on the planet.

reviewText:
Now this is the one everybody remembers.  If you played a PC game in 1995, you played Doom.  Everyone played Doom.  Companies had to institute rules and ban Doom from being played during business hours, because too many employees were playing deathmatches.  Doom was so popular that Microsoft developed a port of it to work on their new Windows 95, in hopes of getting more people to buy the operating system, this of course after Bill Gates toyed with the idea of buying out ID Software all together.

But even with its popularity, there was the mounds of controversy.  Some hated it for its high levels of blood and gore, others for its satanic symbols.  Groups tried to ban it, tried to get it out of the public eye, blamed it for school shootings and random acts of violence.  Many tried to connect it to violent behavior in young adults, citing the violence learned in the game being brought to reality.  But through all of this it stood tall, exactly what it was, simply a game.

Doom is one of those classics that everyone needs to experience   You don’t have to play the whole thing, or beat every level under par.  But every gamer, that wants to truly be a gamer, should spend a little time running around the halls of the UAC facility on the Mars moon.

reviewText: As you can tell by my profile picture, I like this game. I play it again every few years. It's really amazing to see how different first person shooters were when id software was the only one's doing it and had nothing to compare to. You don't look up or down, aiming in the vertical plane is done automatically. There is no commanding officer shouting orders through a radio. The story is told in the instruction manual and by a paragraph at the end of each episode. No need to reload weapons. DOOM was made with one goal in mind: shoot everything and anything that moves. Usually when you play a really old game, you think about how good it would be with modern graphics, but with DOOM there is some sort of uniqueness about its graphics, you don't seem to mind.\n\nBottom Line: DOOM is absolute carnage. A must play.

reviewText: Back in 1993, all we had was MS-DOS and a copy of DOOM. Instead of pressing start on your Xbox Controller, we had to type in terribly long commands. But that long journey was worth it. We got to slaughter demons and destroy Hell itself! Now, we're in an age of Call of Duty and DLC. DOOM has risen to steam as... THE ULTIMATE DOOM! The game works real well and everything just feels like your playing on an old school DOS Computer! To step up the fun, download Brutal Doom. Brutal Doom makes everything better like Fatalities, more gore, and health bonuses for brutally killing Imps and Lost Souls! Another thing that I like about Ultimate Doom is how it includes a fourth episode, Thy Flesh Consumed. It's kinda like a prequel to DOOM II Hell on Earth. If you don't know about this game, you're just a sad shell living under a rock playing Call of Duty Black Ops. Everything about DOOM is just so... AWESOME. If you haven't played this game yet, buy it now on Steam for just $4.99. Overall, The Ultimate DOOM gets a 19/10! Why? BECAUSE IT'S AWESOME!

reviewText:
Welp i have ALOT to say about this version of ultimate doom, i bout it last year and was quickly disappointed because it would not work on my pc although i found a work around to that problem with took a bit but i still did it so for anyone that has had trouble with making this version work i will help. (Works on Windows 8.1 and Windows 10(?) as far as i know.)
!DISCLAIMER! i am not to blame if you mess up your game all i am posting is what i did to fix it
1.Install Doom & Doom II.
2.Right click on doom and choose Properties" go into the "Local File" tab and go to "Browse Local Files".
3.Go into the folder called "Base".
4.Right click doom(.exe) and go into "Properties" and go into the "Compatibility" tab.
5.Change the Compatibility Mode to Windows 95 (dunno why but it works).
6.Then go to "Ultimate(.CONF)" and open it with Notepad.
7.Change "Fullscreen=True" to "Fullscreen=False".
8.Change "Fulldouble=True" to "Fulldouble=False".
9.Change "Waitonerror=True" to "Waitonerror=False".
10.Save the file and go to "Ultimatem(.CONF)".
11.Do the same as you did with "Ultimate(.CONF)".
12.Download ZDoom and run Ultimate Doom.
13.Have fun playing one of the godfathers of the fps genre!"

reviewText: 'Ultimate' DooM may have been ultimate in '95, but nowadays it's basically archaic. I don't even consider the base version playable--an 800x600 window that ♥♥♥♥s up Windows' colors? Eww--Z-Doom is basically required, which gives fullscreen windows, at least 720p and very customizable controls/audio. I'd still recommend Ultimate Z-DooM, but we REALLY need a modern version of this.

reviewText:
It's DOOM. Play this if you like old-school games, gaming history and/or well-designed shooters & somehow haven't tried it yet. What else is there to say about it?


Alright, I'll give it a shot. In 1993, ID Software more or less revolutionized the first-person shooter genre (again) with a game that was not only blazingly fast and good-looking for the time, but played and aged so well it inspired a fanbase that persists to this day.

There have been tens of thousands of custom maps and modifications for Doom and its immediate sequel over the years that take the game in every conceivable direction, and while the 'Doomer' fandom isn't exactly the monstrously huge construction you'd expect to find camping on tumblr*, there's no sign of Doom being truly abandoned any time soon.


You might think, yeah, it was good in its day, but it looks so crude and simple today. Why would anyone still play it? Well, apart from the huge realm of custom content, Doom's gameplay is simply very, very well-tuned. It's a little comparable to bullet hell or chess, in that there's more focus on dodging enemy attacks than there is on tanking them.

Doom's monster AI is simple yet open-ended enough to make for a wide variety of tactical situations, and the player's movement & weaponry aren't any less finely crafted. The one criticism that I can think of is that the gatling gun (which is also incorrectly referred to as a 'chaingun') more or less replaces your starting pistol.

Basically, it's easy to get into, but has enough nuance and depth to carry itself even today. For a while after it was released, games in a similar style were explicitly called 'Doom clones'. To the modern observer, Doom managed to drive progress in the genre enough that in hindsight there really wasn't much shame to be had in being a 'clone' of such an excellent game. (Shoving hundreds of WADs from the Internet into a commercially-released CD was another story.[doom.wikia.com])

You can't look up or down either, at least not in the game's original form. While there's absolutely something to be said for Doom's purity of form (and compensating autoaim), the ability to look in any direction is kind of a boon for newer games.

You probably wouldn't want to play this for the story: you'll literally only find the setup in the game's manual. There's just enough story to justify what's happening in the game, although what's there is good for what it is.

Once the technology was in place, Doom also became a catalyst for early online gaming. This game is, in fact, where the term 'deathmatch' came from. There's still[zandronum.com] options[www.zdaemon.org] available to play Doom with or against other people, without the murderous rates people had to pay 20 years ago. Perhaps bare-bones in comparison to today's offerings, but certainly faster in pace and intensity.


Steam's included DOSBox port is pretty poor, so I would recommend grabbing a sourceport like Chocolate Doom or ZDoom. Those two are my personal favorites - the former lets you experience the game as it was in the '90s, and the latter lets you easily load all sorts of modern mods and enhancements.

Doom's default controls are frankly a relic from the pre-WASD standard days, but fortunately pretty much every sourceport lets you change the controls and even look up & down if you wish. I would recommend at least trying the original controls, though, if you're going to start playing Doom.


If you really want to experience classic Doom, you'd do well to pick up its aforementioned sequel at the very least. It adds new enemies and one new weapon, not to mention 32 new levels, and it's been more popular with custom level designers ever since it came out in 1994. That may not sound like much, but then again, if it ain't broke...

As of this humble summation of Doom, the game in question has persisted for 23 years. I would seriously bet that it will last 23 more.


*Not that I particularly dislike tumblr, of course.

reviewText:
John Stalvern waited. The lights above him blinked and sparked out of the air. There were demons in the base. He didn’t see them, but had expected them now for years. His warnings to Cernel Joson were not listenend to and now it was too late. Far too late for now, anyway.
John was a space marine for fourteen years. When he was young he watched the spaceships and he said to dad “I want to be on the ships daddy.”
Dad said “No! You will BE KILL BY DEMONS”
There was a time when he believed him. Then as he got oldered he stopped. But now in the space station base of the UAC he knew there were demons.
“This is Joson” the radio crackered. “You must fight the demons!”
So John gotted his palsma rifle and blew up the wall.
“HE GOING TO KILL US” said the demons
“I will shoot at him” said the cyberdemon and he fired the rocket missiles. John plasmaed at him and tried to blew him up. But then the ceiling fell and they were trapped and not able to kill.
“No! I must kill the demons” he shouted
The radio said “No, John. You are the demons”
And then John was a zombie.

reviewText: Great fun, this game. I do highly recommend it to anyone who is a PC gamer and doesn't hate fun. There's not much story, so don't be expected to be immersed in that, but the game itself is so fun, I feel like a stroy would ruin everything this game acomplishes. That's another thing, this game doesn't have a verticle axis (looking up and down) so don't complain about that. This was 1993, after all. Anyway, a great PC classic and definitely worth a buy, even though it is possible to get it for free.

reviewText:
What else is there to say about Doom? If you haven't played it you should.

Doom is the forefather of all modern first-person shooters. Its controls are tight, its level design remains some of the best ever achieved in the industry, its music is legendary, and the shotgun blast remains iconic in the world of shooters.

The story is simple, but standard for 1993 games. It begins in the Hangar of the Phobos moon base as the Doomguy fights his way through the forces of hell before arriving on the lost Deimos base. He has to fight his way through even tough challenges here and take down the vile Cyberdemon before descending into Hell itself.

The first nine levels of Doom were released as shareware in 1993. It set a benchmark that future games would dream of reaching. It also had one of the first modding scenes in PC gaming.

Speaking of mods, one of the downsides to Doom, especially the Steam version, is that the controls and settings haven't aged all that well. Thus, I'd recommend using a launcher. I personally use GZDoom, which you can find HERE[www.osnanet.de].

There are other mods that add to the already awesome and timeless gameplay of Doom, specifically the BRUTAL DOOM MOD. This mod adds additional shooting gameplay and a whole lot more blood to the game.

If you are a gamer. Specifically a shooter gamer, you absolurely cannot do much better than Doom.

Further information about Doom can be found in this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x5EfGAA01Gk

Game on and take care.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Taking no credit away from its genre predecessor, Wolfenstein 3-D, DOOM was the breakthrough game of 1993, and the more influential of id's first- person shooters. Its arsenal of powerful guns (namely the shotgun and BFG), intense level of gore and perfect balance of adrenaline-soaked action and exploration kept this gamer riveted for years. Initially a shareware product on PC, DOOM also offered the first multiplayer death- matches via LAN. Doom is creepy, atmospheric, with a sense of impending dread that always seems to be just around the next corner or behind that door. There couldn't have been a better name for the game.

reviewText:
The only reasons for not getting this game are: if you can't stand outdated graphics, if you dislike corridoor FPS, if you demand realism, if you are a specific type of religious person.

The only reason why you should get this game: not a single glaring gameplay flaw. (Use Doom Legacy)

There are many other reasons, the game is fun and challenging, atmosphere is great, there are some puzzles, world records to beat, but these days gameplay mechanics are so messed up in most games, that the primary reason I keep getting back to Doom is to take a rest from cussing at the game.

Although this game has history with some public shooting incidents, sports heavy metal music and you basically play an alternate to Jesus, this is not Postal or Hatred. Romero had originally planned to give the story a much greater importance, but for whatever reason, it did not end up the way it was visioned in The Doom Bible. The final product is a pure shooting gallery and the only objective is to have fun. Finally, how you take it or what you do with it is you problem.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ahhh Doom,now when you start reading this dont think im one of those people that played it when it first came out,anways Doom is one of my favorite games out there its an amazing Classic shooter that in my opinion can still be loads of fun today,The level are amazingly designed Its a fast paced game with fun weapons and is actually a puzzle game believe it or not its never credited for that sadly. I first found out about Doom like 4 years ago and im obsessed with it the only reason it says ive only played for 5 hours is because im playing all sorts of mods source ports and even made a few levels my self,Ive read the whole history of doom and the doom clones and I can go on for ever but im just gonna review the game now.

Gameplay:
Its nice fluid and very fast some people will get mad at the fact that theres no crouching jumping or looking up and down,if that really bothers you please dont miss out and get your self a source port and put those funcions on and have fun it dosent bother me but some people cant stand it,the game is a maze every level with you having to find at leats 2 keys to get through though finding all 3 is best because of all the secret areas they unlock theres hidden doors every where some needing keys,hidden buttons and levers or some just being hidden in the walls slightly discolored from the rest.

Content:
Ultimate doom comes with 4 episodes Knee deep in the dead" "The Shores of Hell" "Inferno" and "Thy Flesh Consumed" each being about nine missions long and being doe in different styles of themes
date:
puzzle types and layout "Knee Deep in the Dead" is a very basic Episode with a few Secret areas  this episode takes place mainly indoors with a few secrets leading outside. "the Shores of Hell" Is my favorite episode with the level design in my opinion truelly being the best taking place mostly indoors from what I can remeber too. Inferno is mainly outside in demon infested areas with lave and rock every where this episode is where doom story wise ends this is my least favorite episode  as it felt kinda easy "Thy Flesh Consumed" was incredibley hard being kind of a sequell to Doom and a backround story for Doom 2 telling you how Doom-Guy got to earth this one is very hard it probabley took me the longest out of all 4 this one is less puzzle solving and more straight foward action you should save often on this one you'll die alot.(I played all 4 on hurt me plenty and beat "Knee Deep in the Dead" On Ultra-Violence)

Cons
(take in mind this game is being run on an amulating source port and is an old game in general)
Multiplayer requires a source port and is not able to run as is I recommend Zandronum for this as Zdeamon is very dead and the community is full of ####faces

9/10 no game is perfect to me though it will always be a 100

reviewText:
I love this game. Love it!!!!

Doom is the first game I ever got truly addicted to, and still to this day I find myself whipping it up on any format I can get it on.
I've had this from the start on Shareware disks of just the first episode, to the full version on PC, Gameboy Advance, N64, iOS, even the RPG version on phone!

The game itself is pretty dated now of course, but that doesn't matter. It just doesn't. This game stands up to the test of time, and is just awesome! Gorey before a game could show individually gibbed body parts, and carrying a deep demonic storyline (i say storyline, it has a basic idea of story from A-B but is no feature length movie-esque COD. Nor does it need to be) and is the true Godfather of the FPS.
There were a few that came before it to set the standard of the 3D element, but THIS is the one that made the effort! Buy it standalone, or buy it as part of the iD pack and try its predecessors too to see what paved the way to this slice of gaming History. Marvel at pixelated blood spatter as you chainsaw a Pinky Demon between the eyeballs, and then laugh as its body rotates on the spot to face you from every angle you look at it (this was a function that was not developed until Quake, i believe?).

Levels are fairly linear - go through a maze of corridors, taking out all foes in your path to collect the keycards to get through the access doors to beat the badassses to destroy the head honcho to save the world. But with loads of guns and loads of ammo and loads of hellish enemies and some proper banging music! Perfect time after time! :D


This game, will ALWAYS be my number one. My first true love.

Always.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: If you've played the shareware version like crazy and have been dying for more, buying this and/or Doom II will not only satisfy you, it'll give you SO MUCH MORE than you expected. Play it on DOSBox or Chocolate Doom for a classic feel or try it on a modern source port such as GZDoom or Zandronum for added graphical effects. Download a few level packs and mods from the thousands available since the 90's.\n\nDoom has an active multiplayer community, It runs on just about anything (new computers, old computers, smartphones, pianos, you name it), and it only costs five bucks. Really, it's hard to come up with reasons why NOT to get this game.

reviewText:
This is what started it all! Its one of the best FPS games that has been developed! The graphics are kind of old but the gameplay never gets old. You can totally blow apart your enemy with a rocket launcher which is fun to do. The codes for this game are simple and ive always remembered them All you have to do is type them in!
IDDQD -- Invulnerability
IDBEHOLDI -- Temporary invisibility
IDBEHOLDR -- Temporary radiation suit
IDBEHOLDS -- Temporary berserk
IDBEHOLDA -- Temporary automap
IDBEHOLDV -- Temporary invulnerability
IDBEHOLDL -- Temporary light
IDKFA -- Full health, ammo, weapons, armor and keys
IDFA -- Full health, ammo, weapons, and armor
IDDT -- Change map detail
IDCHOPPERS -- Gain chainsaw
IDCLEVxx -- Warp to level 'xx' where xx is 01 to 19
IDMYPOS -- Displays your position and bearing
IDMUSxx -- Music select. 'xx' is the level who's song you want.
IDSPISPOPD -- Walk through walls!

reviewText: Ah, what else could be said that hasn't already been said a billion times over with regards to DOOM. This title can really be credited as THE First Person Shooter. With over 20 years time, DOOM continues to have a very much active fan base and has become a milestone for what this genre really represents. For well seasoned gamers you have played of FPS titles such as Unreal Tournament, Quake, Duke Nukem 3D, Wolfenstien, Shadow Warrior, Blood, Rise of the Triad, Painkiller or Serious Sam but not have played DOOM would feel right at home with this game and I would recommend you play this on the harder difficulties or you could download a sourceport for the classic DOOM games for example (Zandronum, GZDoom, ZDoom, DOOMsday etc.) and then get a little mod called Brutal Doom...believe me it's worth the hassle. There are just to many mods and sourceports for DOOM too even mention here. If you are a diehard fan of First Person Shooters and are utterly tired of COD and Battlefield have this genre into...then this is an absolutely must have game for the collection!

Review For Ultimate DoomReview by: Sans

Review :The Ultimate Doom a.k.a Doom 95. An old school first person shooter from the 90's

It's a great game with lots of mods for it. You are a space marine by the game Doomguy"

reviewText:
This is what started it all! Its one of the best FPS games that has been developed! The graphics are kind of old but the gameplay never gets old. You can totally blow apart your enemy with a rocket launcher which is fun to do. The codes for this game are simple and ive always remembered them All you have to do is type them in!
IDDQD -- Invulnerability
IDBEHOLDI -- Temporary invisibility
IDBEHOLDR -- Temporary radiation suit
IDBEHOLDS -- Temporary berserk
IDBEHOLDA -- Temporary automap
IDBEHOLDV -- Temporary invulnerability
IDBEHOLDL -- Temporary light
IDKFA -- Full health, ammo, weapons, armor and keys
IDFA -- Full health, ammo, weapons, and armor
IDDT -- Change map detail
IDCHOPPERS -- Gain chainsaw
IDCLEVxx -- Warp to level 'xx' where xx is 01 to 19
IDMYPOS -- Displays your position and bearing
IDMUSxx -- Music select. 'xx' is the level who's song you want.
IDSPISPOPD -- Walk through walls!

reviewText:
Game Review:
It's Doom. It is one of the greatest games of all time.

Atmosphere:
The atmosphere in Doom is perfect (in the first 3 chapters atleast), and isn't too dark for it's own good. (Like another game later in the franchise).

Story:
The story in this game barely exists, because it doesn't need one. There's demons. Kill them.

Sound:
The music is some of the greatest and some of it is just metal songs from the early 90s in MIDI form.

Weapons:
The main guns you will ever use are the shotgun and plasma gun. The other weapons are good and have their uses, but they aren't AS useful as the first two I mentioned.

Overall:
The orignal 3 chapters of Doom are great and very memorable. However if you're getting this you definintely need to get a source port ( I suggest GZDoom or ZDoom). Everything about this game is great. If you haven't played it you should, and besides it's only $5.

Final Verdict:
Buy it Now

reviewText:
!!Important note!! Doom doesn’t work on my windows 10 laptop it crashes at the start, but it is easily fixable, you can download a launcher called zdoom, which is free and you will be able to easily get the game up and running on it. There is a link below to zdoom.

What I liked about Doom
•	The game has an awesome soundtrack.
•	There are many secrets throughout the levels to be found.
•	The monsters in the game were pretty cool to fight.
•	Awesome levels. My favourite chapter in the game is Inferno
•	A great arsenal of weapons. The shotgun and the chainsaw were my favourite weapons to use. The weapons have a real kick to them, makes you feel like a badass as you go around killing enemies.
•	I liked how at the end of the levels it showed you a map telling you, where you have been and where you are going to next.
•	You can mod the game. Highly recommend you try brutal doom or Project brutality.
• I like it how you can see doomguy's face at the bottom of the screen, seeing how he reacts to being shot at or attacked.

What I disliked or was disappointed with
•	Chapter four isn’t that good. A very difficult chapter, especially at the start.

My conclusion

Doom was one of the first video games I ever played, I have fond memories of it. It is a brilliant first person shooter and made even better with brutal doom or project brutality. I highly recommend it.

83/100

reviewText: This is my favorite game of all time. Not my favorite FPS of all time, My absolute favorite. This game was a technical marvel of its time. If you take the SNES verision of this game and put it next to the PC version, you will see that PC blows console out of the water(As usual).  Now that we have all of the tech and bashing out of the way lets get into the actual game! You are an unnamed space marine for the UAC. You are stationed on one of Mar's moons on a base that has been attacked by the horrors of hell. Enough story I want to shoot some demons! As soon as you press new game, choose which episode you want to play, and which difficulty you want to take on hell with, you are immediately dropped into E1M1, The Hanger, with pistol in hand with demon zombies to kill. There is no health regeneration in this game, no M4 carbine with unlimited ammo, no automatic checkpoints, and no hand holding what so ever. As soon as the level starts you are on your own to kill and explore. That is the beauty of this game there is no restriction on where you can go. If you see an area with bad guys outside? You can go there. You see a chain saw and you want it more than anything in the world? Look for a wall to open and go get it and find some meat! The gameplay is the best thing about this game. The primal satisfaction from seeing that enemy go down in a bloody gorey mess from the blast of your shot gun is like no other. The story is there, but it never really matters that much. John Carmack, the lead programmer for the game, has stated this hilarious phrase, Story in a game is like a story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there
date: but it's not that important." The music in this game is absolutely phenomenal. At DOOM's gate
hoursPlayed: is ingrained into every person who has played this game. The music is down and dirty metal. It fits the game very well. All in all

reviewText:
If you buy this, or any of the other classic DOOM games, you have 2 options to have a decent experience:

1: Get the .WAD files and use them with a source port of your choice, however this wont track your stats on steam.

2: Put a source port in the game directory and rename the source port exe to 'dosbox.exe' and delete the original dosbox of course. This will let you run a source port and still have Steam track game time and show when you're playing it.

Don't even bother using the DOSbox emulation that comes with it, it has performance issues, runs in an awful resolution, has awful sound emulation, and has no mouse look option whatsoever, if you plan on playing it 100% faithful to the original DOS experience, don't use DOSbox, build or buy a 486.

Wait, a review for the game? Saying great things about it is basically copypasta at this point, you've heard it before.

reviewText: The game that is nostalgic for some, including myself. I used to sit at my dad's PC and play this game non-stop. Constantly replaying Knee Deep in the Dead, it being my favorite episode. Knowing all of the secrets, weapon locations, enemy types. Ah.. Thankfully the 2016 DOOM stays true to it instead of trying to pull what Doom 3 did. Doom 3 wasn't a bad game, it just wasn't a good Doom game. This game can be made better through programs like GZDoom, Zandronum and a few others. Some of these mods even  including PvP multiplayer and a co-op campaign experience. The game is inexpensive, and hella fun. I'd say get it and run it through Zandronum for some multiplayer with friends.

reviewText: What can you say about this game? It's one of the kings of the FPS genre and was a cultural phenomenon when it was released. The graphics, the music, and the gameplay were all done perfectly, not overshadowing one another. The game is easy to pick up and play, but it can definitely be a challenge to master. You'll get so good at it after awhile that you don't even have to think about shooting; it'll come natural. My only gripe with the game (specifically with The Ultimate DOOM, not the base DOOM game released first) is that Episode 4 is a bit lackluster and just doesn't feel as polished as the first three episodes. Other than that, this is the one game everyone has to play before they die.

reviewText:
A game that wasn't the first to do it, but was the first to do it right.

A combination of a simple but effective aresenal, fast (like 50mph fast) movement, a tense, dark atmosphere and 36 well paced (both in difficulty and item progression) labyrinthine levels that can either make you feel like a total Bad Dude mowing down tons of shotgun daddies, or have you on your toes, fighting for survival. Blasting your way through the adorable, yet terrifying cast of hellspawn in search of a way out is still the most satisfying mechanical experience you could have on A Personal Computing Device.

one that hasn't been successfully matched in 23 years

one with an endless amount of community-created content, from well crafted packs that replace the 3 episodes, many infamous maps that are great for a quick laugh, single maps that continue to push the limits of what a 1993 game is capable of. [the majority of wads are designed for doom 2, get that one too]

and if it's your thing, there are gameplay mods that totally ruin alter what is already great gameplay and are enjoyable for about five minutes at the most and are a disgrace to one of the finest peices of interactive entertainment.


I would definitely recommend using a source port when playing on a modern [not DOS] system, there are many out there which all fill a necessary hole. I recommend Chocolate Doom [designed to be as close to the original executable as possible, with bugs and limits] and Doom Retro [based on an earlier version chocolate doom with less bugs and minor enhancments but still keeps the gritty vibe and vanilla gameplay]. there are a few others, but the other one i would recommend is ZDoom [not gzdoom], as that works with the majority of user-made content and is definitely user-friendly. This isn't an absoulte list of what you need to use, but i highly discourage jumping in whatever port you decide on. that completely ruins many of the levels in the game.

this game and its sequel have consumed me for 12 years off and on. still one of my all time favorites
buy the pack with Doom II+master levels and Final Doom instead of Whatever Your Vice Of Choice Is

best played on a software renderer, capped at 35 FPS at 320X200.

Keyboard only if you're feeling courageous
