reviewText:
Uh oh! The map is being overrun by enemies! Do you:

A. Escort a poorly programmed essential A.I. through monotonous level design for a QTE finale?
B. Grind your way through ham-fisted and mind-numbing exposition atop consecutive turret sections?
C. Hold down the fire button as the rail-shooter pulls you through an abysmal excuse of a narrative?

The correct answer?
D, baby. D is for Doom.

Your mission is simple: rip and tear your way through the hordes of hell with your arsenal of bloody mayhem, experiencing the revolutionary shooter that set the world afire and the tears of outrage and controversy flowing.

The godfather of the FPS genre is still in excellent shape, even after more than twenty years since release. Don't let the system requirements put you off, this runs perfectly well on new operating systems with a few tweaks. It's pretty easy to take for granted from a modern perspective what games such as Doom, System Shock and Half-Life had on the gaming industry upon their release; almost single-handedly creating and then revolutionising the FPS genre. The phenomenal response to the shareware release of Doom and it's colossal (and enduring) success is due to absolutely nailing the formula and standard that id had previously set with Wolfenstein.

From the exceptional level design, full of secrets and opportunities for your trusty shotgun to earn its keep, to the brilliant soundtrack backed by excellent sound design as yet another imp is blown away, Doom is everything that many shooters have forgotten: Simple, bloody, fast and instantly gratifying chaos.
When was the last time you played something that was this much fun?

Too outdated for you? Then install Brutal Doom, the Project Brutality add-on or various source ports to bring the blood into a whole new era. Welcome back, marine.

Good? Bad? I'm the guy with the gun." Hell awaits."

reviewText: What is there to say about Doom that hasn't already been said? Seriously, if you've never played or heard of Doom, where have you been?! BUY THIS GAME! It's my favorite FPS game of all time, and it's still hours upon hours of fun. And WADs make it even better. I rate Doom an easy 10/10.

reviewText: The Ultimate Doom is simply an upgraded version of the Original Doom game. I’m going to go ahead and tell you now, there is a good chance of getting eye cancer after play this game, yes it looked that horrendous. It looks great if you’re staring at your screen from afar, but close up these graphics are pixelated. Yeah it’s an old game, but after playing all the modern games you may or may not be able to adapt to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics. If you aren’t able to adapt you may be facing many hours of dizziness and nausea while playing this game. Overall this game was wonderful, the sound effects were very retro but still sounded clear and crisp. The controls were a little wonky and take a little getting used to because you can’t really move your mouse vertically in this game. Believe it or not this game actually has replayability, just mod out the doom mobs and turns them in to Barnies and/or Teletubbies!

reviewText:
Putting myself into the shoes of a gamer in '93, Doom would have blown me away. Sure, the arcades were feeling Sega's games like Virtua Racing, but somehow managing to get a 3D shooter to run at 25-30 fps purely through DOS, that will run on a home PC in '93 just amazes me. Some very sneaky tricks must have been used to get that '3D' effect working in DOS. With good sound, good level design, and just a very classic feel to it, the overall experience feels like a primitive (but still very enjoyable) form of the games we have today.

Back then, it would've really stood out. I say this without nostalgic bias, as I wasn't even alive at the time of release, but I can still see the serious jump Doom had over Wolfenstein 3D, or Pathways Into Darkness by Bungie for the Macintosh. ID Software really had the ball rolling here, with 4 player Deathmatch support, and being a key icon in popularising the fps genre, I'm going to have to hand it to them, it's hard to make a game that will still be enjoyable decades later.

For its time, I'd give it a solid 9/10.

reviewText:
Oddly enough, I played DOOM II before DOOM in 95, so this was really my second installment in the series, about two years later.

Back in 1995 things were simpler — I only had DOOM II, and Hover! so I could just play the obvious choice; come 1996 and (Final) DOOM, and choices were not that easy anymore: there also were Grand Prix 2 and FIFA 97 to be taken care of. Well, even though the choice wasn't easy, it always boiled down to my favourite meat-grinding, first-person gore party.

I believe — and this is probably just my heart talking — DOOM II was far better than the original, but even then I knew perfectly that this would be a milestone, this would matter, this would've made history.

It's not too late to claim your part in it.

reviewText:
The legendary first-person shooter that put the genre on the map. Best enjoyed with a source port to enable modern controls and settings.

PROS:
+ Satisfying weaponry
+ Memorable soundtrack
+ Fast-paced, intuitive gameplay
+ Excellent sound and level designs
+ Iconic visuals and monster designs
+ Plenty of custom levels and mods available

CONS:
- Anticlimactic boss fights
- Frustratingly difficult bonus fourth Episode

reviewText:
I bought this on Steam just so I could write a review of it, and maybe push id in the right direction with sales. I have actually played this game for hundreds of hours. I probably play it for at least 10-20 hours per year, for every year of my life.

Let me make one thing perfectly clear: nostalgia does not factor into this game's enjoyment. Doom still has a very active community, and new mods come out all the time. Thanks to Carmack's programming, Doom made modding a staple of PC gaming, and it hasn't gone away. Getting older has made me see more of Doom's flaws, but I don't really like it any less.

Doom is far from perfect. Unlike modern corridor shooters, which almost completely abandon the principles of level design, Doom is made or broken by its level design. There are a few different level designers that worked on Doom, and once you've played enough you can tell each of them just by playing their levels, even if you don't know their names. This means that level design is inconsistent, and therefore you're going to really like some levels and hate others. Most people who played Doom as a kid forgave the bad levels because, well, they were kids. If you're new to Doom, it's best to start at the beginning and play Episode 1 of Doom 1. This is widely regarded as one of the best, if not the best, set of levels for Doom, designed by John Romero. They're coherent, look nice (relatively speaking) and have well-placed secrets. Oddly enough, Doom 64 has one of the best sets of levels and plays like any of the other classic Doom games; google Doom 64 Absolution" and you can easily find a total conversion mod that basically allows you to play Doom 64 on your computer once you have Doom. Thanks

reviewText:
How can I describe my thoughts on this game from what I have played in the last 10 mins?

The answer would be by telling you how within the first level of the game I was on the edge of my seat. I relished every shotgun shell I found, loving and caring for it until I found a home for it in someones skull. I feared the moment I had when I first saw that bull demon thing, with only a pistol and my wits. I smiled as I found the chaingun for the first time and cleared an entire room in a single blast.

If you are considering buying this game and you are a fan of true run and gun gameplay, this is the big daddy of them all, and I'm saying this having only played 10 mins. It is every bit worth every cent it cost to buy.

Good luck and welcome to your Doom.

reviewText: The Ultimate Doom takes the exceptional and timeless first person shooting classic Doom and adds a single new episode to the already three episode game. The problem with the Steam version is that it comes with an old version of DOSBox which crashes on startup. That's probably why this game is on sale so often for as cheap as it is. Sure you can download a new version of DOSBox or even go find a great source port like GZDoom to run the game, but the fact is one of the two of them should come with this Steam version. It should work out of the box, otherwise, I can go tell you go find a PC from the 90s and you'll be fine playing this." Why should there be that extra step involved? When you buy a hot dog
date: does the vendor tell you go across the street to cook it? What's odd is that Doom 2 works with its DOSBox
recommended: but the Master Levels and Final Doom crash on startup.\n\nIf you really want to play the game straight out of the box
hoursPlayed: the Doom 3: BFG Edition comes with a playable version of Doom 1
voteText: Doom 2
helpfulPercent: the Master Levels for Doom 2 and more. That's what you want to pick up. You can still use source ports
votesHelpful: mods and .wad files for that. What if you need the Ultimate Doom? There are Doom bundles on Steam that you should look into as a cheaper alternative to purchasing just this game.\n\nDoom lives on forever. Its a game that's over twenty years old has been kept alive by the fans and its still going strong today with mods. I've played Doom over twenty years on multiple source ports with multiple .wad level packs made by the community. The source ports are engines to run the old game on modern technology. There are dozens of them
votesTotal: all free. I mentioned GZDoom before
votesFunny: and that's the finest way to play Brutal Doom that everyone has been talking about for the past year or more.\n\nFor those unaware
commentsCount: who have made it past my explanation
column16: Doom is the father of all first person shooters and its predecessor Wolfenstien 3D is the grandfather or great grandfather at this point. Before first person shooters had their own genre
column17:
they were called Doom clones.

There is no story here beyond the back story that's unavailable unless you have the instruction manual from two decades ago. Demons have invaded and its up to only you. There are a few cut scenes after each episode as a reward and a calm moment to take a breather from all the chaos.

Doom puts you down into a science fiction
column19: almost psychotic setting on Phobos for the first episode. Then Diemos for the second
column20: and Hail itself for the third. Where the game becomes Ultimate Doom is that fourth challenging
column21: tough and yet fun fourth campaign.\n\nAlthough Ultimate Doom came after Doom 2
column22: the elements of Ultimate Doom are only from the original game. There are no new weapons
column23: enemies or anything else other than a new orange sky for the fourth episode. Its more of the same fantastic game.\n\nSo what makes Doom so fantastic? Its simplicity. You are alone
column24: kill everything that moves. Doom is known for being unable to move your mouse up or down. If an enemy is above or below you
column25: your character will still shoot them
column26: but you just have no way to look down on them.\n\nDoom's combat is fast paced. Your character already moves fast
column27: he can strafe and turn at a swift speed
column28: but then he can also run to dash over small gaps. There is no jump button
column29: why would you need one when you can dodge everything and the game is full of staircases and lifts to take you where you need to go.\n\nBeyond fast paced action
column31: open doors and hump walls looking for secret entrances. If you ever get lost
column32: there's an easy to use map. There's a lot of exploration in the game and for every eight levels per episode there's a hidden secret level. You'll find soul spheres
column33: backpacks that let you double your maximum amount of ammunition. Armor will take some damage and you'll need med kits and stim packs to restore your health.\n\nDeath will restart the level with a mere pistol
column34: but you can save as often as you'd like. Every trap that has you falling into toxic waste
column35: lava or something that hurts you will always have a platform to lower so you can escape. Its always a fair game like that.\n\nAt the end of each level
column39: secrets and items. Having percentages and times is a good take on a score to keep you immersed in the game. There are five levels of difficulty. The nightmare requires a lot more strategy because enemies respawn a brief time after you've slaughtered them.\n\nIn terms of weapons
column41: there's a shotgun that you can use as a sniper rifle. A chaingun that uses pistol ammunition
column42: a plasma rifle that does more damage. Then there's a rocket launcher that does splash damage and you can watch enemies explode into mush. To top it all off
column43: you'll find the BFG 9000 that uses plasma rifle's cell ammunition
column44: but it can wipe out a lot of enemies. Its one of the more fastening weapons. It takes a moment to fire
column45: it has a giant slow particle that when it smashes against something it melts a large radius of enemies.\n\nThe environments diverse array of colors and areas feel different from one another. Metallic bases
column50: walls of faces and marble structures. Areas are bright
column52: others have flickering lights. This is a horror action game rather than a scary atmospheric romp. Just know your shotgun will keep you safe and even when you're out of bullets you can run faster than a sports car. Who needs to run though when you have your fists and can find a chainsaw?\n\nThe enemies are a nice diverse array of creatures that ramp up as the game progresses. There is a set of two zombie soldiers
column54: the other with a shotgun. These two are more of a challenge to grant you a bit of ammunition. They still manage to be dangerous on higher difficulties
column56: meaning that if they can see you.\n\nLarger foes like imps throw fireballs that let you dodge them before they hit you. Cacodemons hover and posture to belch lightning balls at you. Pinkie demons and spectres take a lot of damage and get in your face
column57: but they're still quick enough to dodge your crosshair when they're a distance away. Lost souls dash forward and bash into you. Barons are grand versions of imps that throw plasma balls and take a lot of punishment. Beyond those enemies are two bosses that cap off the second and third episodes. A giant beast with a rocket launcher as an arm and a spider mastermind with a chaingun hitscan weapon that will keep hitting you with no cover.\n\nThe Ultimate Doom is a fantastic game
column58: its just that it should be playable when you buy it. However
column59: Doomers are known for digging through folders and getting programs to work. There are a lot of ways to get this to work and chances are if you're reading this you've already played Doom before
column61: but play it elsewhere than this specific version."

reviewText:
Honestly, it's a bit clunky. Not being able to look up or down is always annoying. Even worse, moving the mouse forward or back instead moves me forwards or backwards, which is really annoying when I'm trying not to fall. I mean, seriously, what FPS does that, having the mouse move the player? It goes against every gaming instinct I've developed from FPSs.
As far as I know, there's no way to change the controls, so I'm stuck with this bass ackwards mouse control.
Other than that, there's not much to say. I mean, it's the original DOOM, pretty much. An all-time classic. I would say it's aged relatively well. Graphics can get repetitive, what you have to do isn't always straightforward, and some times the game makes you jump through extra hoops just for some cheap hits (if I remember correctly, in E1M4, you have to get the red keycard, which sets off a flag for more enemies to be released, and you have to get through them to get the blue keycard). But overall, it's fun, it's challenging, and it's DOOM.

Hell awaits you... Are you ready for it?

reviewText:
Will not run on Windows 8 systems, no game that's continuing to be sold should have these compatibility issues.

This is the modern age, despite this being an old game, this should not be continually sold while these problems persist.  DO NOT BUY if you are running Windows 8, and I wouldn't chance it if you've got 8.1.  This is a lazy port, a mere cash grab, otherwise this would not be a problem

To everyone else, I hope you're enjoying this classic!  Kick some extra ♥♥♥ for me, won't you? :)

EDIT: After a bit of messing with it I actually got it to work, albeit with some weird tricks.  Still leaving this as a Not recommended" though since it's STILL a cashgrab that could have been set up better so that users didn't have to mess with it to make it work."

reviewText:
The Ultimate in Bad Ports.

If you couldn't tell from the official screenshots with warped colors, this features terrible modern hardware support. How bad? No OpenGL/DirectX. Software Rendering Only. Locked 480p 4:3 Resolution. This is only worth buying for the data files, which you should proceed to use in a newer Source Port engine.

This is the roots of PC Gaming on Windows people thanks to Gabe Newell who offered to port it." -Just Good PC Games

The above statement is an obviously paid lie. Calling this a port at all is outright dishonest. This crap got shoved onto steam when Bethesda got the Id catalog
date: and it's an outdated unpatched dos version running in an emulator. Gabe did nothing
recommended: and in no way is this a Windows NT port
hoursPlayed: but a disgusting cashgrab by Bethesda using a DOS emulator they also didn't develop.\n\nAny other avenue for legally acquiring those files is better than this. This is an awful hackjob that no one should support Bethesda with. If you don't believe me
voteText: go look at Super Noah's Ark 3-D. There is nothing preventing these games from running the way they should but Bethesda.\n\nIf you buy this and don't leave an extremely negative review

You can't play this as it ships and leave with a good impression unless you are a fool completely ignorant of PC Gaming and DOOM. As someone who has spent hundreds of hours playing DOOM
votesHelpful: as someone who considers DOOM to be in the high end of their Top 5 Games of All Time
votesTotal: this is not how you should experience doom. Buyer Beware."

reviewText: This game is a timeless classic and if you don't have it in your Steam library you are not a gamer (Unless you still have the original game sitting on your old CD shelf waiting to be played. Get out of here.  You don't belong here. The difficulty will have you raging but it is so satisfying when you finally beat the Spider Mastermind. And then, of course, there is one new episode to conquer, your childhood memories don't have to end. And even after that. You still have the multiplayer mode which seems impossible on today's computer. Well, then you download Zandronum and Skulltag and start deathmatching again. And then, you can mod your game with Brutal Doom, Doom 3 weapons, Real Guns Hardcore, etc. The possibilities are endless with this game. And the adventure continues with Doom 2. The fun never ends.

reviewText:
DOOM is a great game, and it's an awesome experience for any FPS player. It's not one of those games that has you going straight from point A to point B. You have to explore the maps to find keys that you to proceed to the next map. There is a wide mariety of maps, this version of DOOM has a total of 36 maps if you also count the secret maps. Some maps can be a maze, however, and it can ruin the pace of the game. The game also has a lot of secrets and even a few secret levels. DOOM also has a good variety of enemies, some can be annoying though, such as the Lost Souls, the pinky Demons with partial invisibility, and the Cacodemons. The bosses are probably the most badass bosses in gaming, a giant robot demon with a rocket launcher for a hand, and a robot spider demon with a chaingun. I won't count the bruiser brothers, because they're just two Barons of Hell. The game also offers some kick ♥♥♥ music, which adds good pace to the game, although some songs can be a bit boring, but most of them are awesome. It has some really neat powerups such as +100% health, invinsibility, increased damage, +200% armor, partial invisibility, a sphere that brings your health and armor to the max (200%), and a radiation suit. You start with 2 weapons, your fists, and a pistol. The other weapons, which you earn as you progress through the game are a shotgun, a chaingun, a rocket launcher, a plasma gun, and the almighty BFG 9000, this weapon is a beast and can kill multiple enemies with one hit, and it's also an easy way to quickly end a boss fight, but it is very overpowered, and might ruin the fun unless you're a psychopath, which you probably are if you can't stay away from DOOM. The gameplay is quite simple, find what you need to continue to the next map and shoot whatever is alive. No living thing here is your friend. The controls can be awkward for players, you use the up and down arrow keys to move forwards and backwards, and the left and right arrow keys to turn left and right, left control shoots, alt strafes, shift sprints, and space flicks switches and pushes buttons, they aren't rebindable. But you can still use GZDoom, which has rebindable keys mouse looking, and it allows you to move left and right. And GZDoom also quickly starts the game, which is something we should really thank the dudes who made GZDoom for because the game takes about a minute to finally get to the main menu.

TL;DR: Doom is awesome, some things can be a bit meh, GZDoom can fix some flaws. My individual rating the aspects I talked about are:

Gameplay: 10/10
Enemies: 8/10
Map design: 8/10
Music: 9/10
Weapons: 8/10
Controls: 6/10 (GZDoom fixes that)
Time to load the game: 0/10 (GZDoom makes is a 10/10)
Simplicity: 10/10
Bosses: 8/10
Powerups: 10/10
Maps: 7/10

Overall score: 7.6/10

reviewText: What can I say about this game that hasn't been said a billion times over? The granddaddy of all first person shooters. The orignal, the classic, and arguably the best. This game remains the epitome of what FPS games should be. A benchmark for all companys seeking to create a fully featured shooter. Doom has a wide range of weapons, excellent combat, it's challenging, and immensly fun. Even to modern standards, it kicks ♥♥♥. In it's time, there was nothing like it. Guns guns guns and monsters. Blood, guts, glory, and the salvation of the human race.\n\nIt goes without saying, if you love FPS games and haven't played Doom even once, you aren't doing it right. This game is a MUST for all FPS lovers. Learn some history about your favorite genre while you blast away at demons with your trusty shotgun. Experience the game that created and shaped a whole new niche of gaming. I can go on forever about this game. It truly is, and will forever be, an incredible game.

reviewText:
Where has this game been all my life? Honestly, I never expected it to be more fun than I thought it'd be.

Run around, shoot demons, collect guns, shoot demons, collect ammo, shoot demons, collect armor, shoot demons, collect powerups, shoot demons, collect keycards, open doors, push buttons, flip switches, find secrets, and shoot demons. So simple yet so elegant.

However, the control just doesn't hold up today. So the solution to that is to download a sourceport! There are quite a few out there, but I most reccommend GZDoom. You just need to first configure the controls and stuff and you'll be all set! It'll feel like a modern FPS in no time.

And then there's the mod Brutal Doom. More blood, more gore, prettier visual effects, new sprites, new functioning weapons, different customizations for the mod, just overall brilliant.

Buy the Doom Classic Complete pack. It'll be well worth it.

Rip and tear! Rip and tear their guts!

reviewText:
I can't stop playing Doom and its sequels.  With a modern source port such as GZDoom the game is fantastic and far more fun than any modern shooter I can think of.  No hand holding, no tutorials, no cut scenes, just you and your shotgun!

Once you have bought this masterpiece the fun is only just getting started.  You will then be able to gain access to a massive amount of mods, custom levels, complete game makeovers and all sorts.  www.doomworld.com is a good place to start.

I would also strongly recommend that you try out Brutal Doom.  Many Doom purists dislike it, but whilst I really love the original games and play style, Brutal Doom is just all out adrenaline and is a fantastic achievement really.

11/10 - This game has never been bettered and it will never die.  Better than any other FPS ever made, including Half Life and ID's own Quake series.

reviewText:
The second title in Id's monumental trilogy of FPS franchises to set the 90's on fire (with the other two being Wolfenstein and Quake). Rather than settle for awkward middle child status, Doom is arguably the more beloved than it's siblings. This is no surprise, given it's excellent weapons (including the début of the iconic BFG 9000), morbid art design and excellent midi metal sound track.
Level design is certainly an improvement over it's spiritual predecessor Wolfenstein, but it still often boils down to a lengthy corridor maze. At least brown is less an eyesore than teal.

BFG9000 out of Ten

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It's amusing why I'm writting this, since it's DOOM for ♥♥♥♥ sake, but I'll get to it. Anyway for those that have experienced this game all those years ago and haven't touched it since, I advise to pick it up, play, to relieve the nostalgia, then hop onto the mod scene for a kick in the nuts surprise. Anyway, it is one of the first FPS games that started the genre and got me interested in it. (Though to be fair Duke Nukem 3D was the real spark for me for shooters, and Quake was what got me into competitive MP portion of the genre).

The vanilla experience is extremely dated, no proper aiming, clunky controls by today's standard, heavy reliance on auto aim and naturaly the primitive graphics. Even with all that I played the vanilla recently (though I ended up modding it via zdoom for better control scheme) and still was fun as ever. Secrets were ♥♥♥♥ well hidden (for those that I couldn't remember), shooting still felt great. Amusing how a primitive shooter like Doom can have such great shooting feeling. Enemies will flinch depending on guns, rockets will gib and blast stuff apart and BFG will clear rooms. The level design was fantastic, mazelike key hunting formula that made a lot of old games great, and put a large majority of modern games to shame when it comes to inteligent level design. While I had an absolute blast with Doom, and not just due to nostalgia, I encountered the large amount of fantastic mods.

At first I take this with a grain of salt. Mods for games are peculiar, usually extremely specific, niche or such. Here or there there will be some that truly stand out. In Doom's case, good God are there a lot of great mods. I'm not going to rattle them off but I will mention one particular mod that enhances the experience to modern standars, and puts to shame almost every known FPS developer today. I'm talking about Brutal Doom mod. If you liked doom, any iteration of it, go look this up. It takes the entire old game/s and tuns it to 11 with gore, weapons, effects, sound and feeling. To me this mod made Doom game so much more in standard with current games. Doom already was a pinacle, had nothing to prove since it stood among the first and best, but with mods like this it really makes me ask: what the ♥♥♥♥ are current FPS devs doing.

The original game is timleess, and while I admit there is some nostalgia there, there are still a lot of technical aspects (gameplay wise) that hold strong even 20 years after. With mods (like Brutal Doom), all bets are off, this is balls to the walls amazing value in a game that offers everything a shooter should have. Shooting is fun, satisfying, strategic, skill based, and no matter how much they throw at you you will want more to paint the walls with (that is quite literal in Brutal Doom's case).

If you feel that game requires fancy graphics to be good, you are in the wrong game genre. This game right here does everything justice in terms of shooting, level exploration, wit, and just not giving a ♥♥♥♥. Go to hell, and make them sorry they ever heard of you.

reviewText: What can I say about this game that hasn't been said a billion times over? The granddaddy of all first person shooters. The orignal, the classic, and arguably the best. This game remains the epitome of what FPS games should be. A benchmark for all companys seeking to create a fully featured shooter. Doom has a wide range of weapons, excellent combat, it's challenging, and immensly fun. Even to modern standards, it kicks ♥♥♥. In it's time, there was nothing like it. Guns guns guns and monsters. Blood, guts, glory, and the salvation of the human race.\n\nIt goes without saying, if you love FPS games and haven't played Doom even once, you aren't doing it right. This game is a MUST for all FPS lovers. Learn some history about your favorite genre while you blast away at demons with your trusty shotgun. Experience the game that created and shaped a whole new niche of gaming. I can go on forever about this game. It truly is, and will forever be, an incredible game.

reviewText: I was wrong about this game. I had trouble enjoying it, until I started playing it on easy mode through a third-party Doom engine like Doomsday or ZDoom. Doomsday has an option to disable the motion-sickness-inducing view bobbing, and has a map overlay that makes navigating the byzantine levels more fun for a modern gamer. Easy mode is built in to the regular game (there are 5 difficulty settings, and the default is the one in the middle), and I found it much more fun to treat the game like a shooting gallery in a maze (with a map that fills out as you go through the level) than a tough as nails, player versus the world hellscape.\n\nThere are people who played Doom when it came out and still love the original game for what it is. The majority of current FPS gamers have never played it, but they should. Maybe they can't appreciate it in the same way as the original fans, but if they're like me they can still enjoy the incredible shooting mechanics. Among all first-person shooters, this game has one of the best and most satisfying to use shotguns, for example.

reviewText: I remember playing this for the first time when I was around 4 years old. My Dad bought it for our PC and I would sit and play Doom with him (not the best game for a four year old). Now I am 21 and I still love this game. In terms of first person shooting this is the origin, and still the master. It has never aged and still produces one of the most challenging FPS experiences I have ever faced. Enemies can still surprise you no matter how many times you have played through it and the eerie noises and distant grunts of imps can still install fear into any player. The graphics still dont look that much dated considering when it came out, and the gameplay is second to none. Even after all these years of playing Doom and the Doom franchise I still come back to it whenever I fancy a shooting spree on some grunts and imps. Overall it is my favourite game ever and will continue to be for many years to come

reviewText:
In the modern age of first person shooters such as CoD and Battlefield with their stylized presentation and Quicktime events it is a welcome and joyous occasion when you can fire up a game of Doom and be sucked in like it was 1993 all over again.

On the outside Doom is just another retro shooter trying to survive in this modern world. With it’s pixelated 2.5D graphics, midi soundtrack, inability to jump or duck or even look in 3 dimensions, you would think that it would have been long forgotten in a wash of newer, flashier combat games, but that’s where Doom really shines. In its minimalistic nature, Doom makes you forget what it doesn’t have and focus on what it does have: amazing gameplay.

Doom doesn’t hold your hand. Right from the start you are thrust into a foreign Martian world with a pistol and the hope of survival as you are faced with ever increasing opposition which comes in the form of possessed Space Marines and demonic creatures straight from the depths of hell, and over time that’s exactly where you go. Through the game you get access to bigger and badder weapons but also find larger and more dangerous enemies such as the Cyberdemon and the Spiderdemon-both a mix of demonic flesh and futuristic machine a perfect parallel to the twisted world around them-to use them on. Through it all, superior level design and your wits are what separate you from the dead marines at your feet. The levels unobtrusively lead you into your next surprise encounter all the while providing the cover needed to save you from near death. One thing they don’t do is raise that veil of atmosphere that Doom lays on you. All of the pieces fit together wonderfully in this game to give you the perfect immersive experience.

Of course, one of the biggest reasons this game is still relevant today is the still thriving community of modders who create everything from single levels to entire modifications for the game that give you new weapons, enemies, graphics, sounds, levels, game mechanics… even huge multiplayer and coop levels. And it’s all free.

If you are looking for an adrenaline rush or just want to run screaming down memory lane, look no further than Doom.

Oh man, did I love every bit of this game.  This is the original DOOM and the first couple of extra episodes.  These levels are quite basic since they are motly find the keys and open the doors.  Has a few large open levels, but not anywhere near as much as Final DOOM or DOOM II.

This game is a BLAST to play, even today.  You run fast, shoot fast, all the guns are awesome, and for some reason the atmosphere is still kind of surprising and creepy after all these years.

I totally recommend this for those that never played it, but like scary FPS games:  or for those that want to re-live the game again.  - Tons of Mods to make this game even more awesome out there.

reviewText: Doom is proof that while technological supremacy is fleeting, good game design is forever. Twenty-plus years after its release, it still stands tall as one of the greatest first person shooters ever made, an orgy of twitchy bloody death and destruction matched only by its own sequel. All the game needs to make you forget it came out in the early 90's is a fresh coat of paint, and all it takes is a few free downloads to cover that. GZDoom ports the game engine to run natively on windows, instead of requiring DOSbox, and gives the game a host of modern conveniences features like fully 3D environment rendering, texture filtering, and most importantly, proper mouse look. Brutal Doom, probably one of the best and most comprehensive mods ever made, fills out the package by overhauling the soundtrack, adding buckets and buckets of gore, and rebalancing the gameplay to be faster and more intense than ever.\n\nIf you're willing to take a few minutes to set it up properly, Doom is absolutely worth your time. It was great then, and thanks to twenty years of technical advancements and a somewhat overzealous fan community, it's even better now.

reviewText:
Doom was one of the very first FPS and helped massivley progress the genre into one of the biggest video game genres out there. I had heard all this and much more about how amazong this game was yet I was hugley sceptical of the as I belived it must be alot of nostaliga that is affecting people view on the game.

So I bought the game to try it out myself, at first I wasn't keen on it atall as im used to modern titles such as COD and battlefield. But onec I got into the game I realized I was have so much more fun than I did on say a call of duty campaign. The graphics are bad and you cant look up or down but it didn't affect me atall as the game is just so much fun.

reviewText:
DOOM!

As old as it may be, this game has aged quite well compared to many other FPS games. Even despite its age it still feels unique and once you get used to mouse controls, feels so very tight and responsive.

It's a great game to throw yourself back into the days before cover shooting and rechargable health/shields and quicktime events and linear cooridoor level design. You'll find yourself seeking out each secret to get the most badass weapons. You could play at your own pace: carefully exploring every step of the way to survive or just simply running out guns blazing, leaving a trail of destruction in your wake.

WARNING: This game will leave you wanting more in your other FPS; something more than Bay-esque scripted explosions, something more than NPCs running around you to shoot the things you're stuck on. Luckily there is DOOM II to fill that itching desire.

reviewText: What can I say about this game that hasn't been said a billion times over? The granddaddy of all first person shooters. The orignal, the classic, and arguably the best. This game remains the epitome of what FPS games should be. A benchmark for all companys seeking to create a fully featured shooter. Doom has a wide range of weapons, excellent combat, it's challenging, and immensly fun. Even to modern standards, it kicks ♥♥♥. In it's time, there was nothing like it. Guns guns guns and monsters. Blood, guts, glory, and the salvation of the human race.\n\nIt goes without saying, if you love FPS games and haven't played Doom even once, you aren't doing it right. This game is a MUST for all FPS lovers. Learn some history about your favorite genre while you blast away at demons with your trusty shotgun. Experience the game that created and shaped a whole new niche of gaming. I can go on forever about this game. It truly is, and will forever be, an incredible game.

reviewText:
With all of the first person classics I have played lately. Games like Team Fortress 2, Metroid other M, and the many games with first person moments in game.  You really learn to appreciate where stuff had its real start.   Sure the graphics are really dated by today's standereds. The game play is simple, and the story well, isn't really needed.
You are here, You have a pistol, You see tons of fellow characters dead on the floor, and everything is trying to kill you.  You are awesome, so you Fight back.

This game has alot of the elements used in modern games.  Mini maps, Changing weapons such as the pistol, Shotgun, and my personal fave, the Chain gun.   To a lesser extent there is the worry about ammo loss, You dont regenerate so you actually have to watch your health amount and Armor remaining.   To be honest this game is actually alot harder now that I played games like Halo and Tf2.     I honestly belive that any fan of FPS games be it Tf2, those army COD games, or just shooters in general should come and try this and maybe Quake too.   IF for nothing else than to see the place here FPS REALLY began. [I have played Wolfen stein.. and yes it was first.. but Doom is FAR better in my opinion.]
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Do you remember DOOM? The old grandpa of first person shooters? Well I don't. I wasn't born when it came out. But in the year of 2009 I found out about this miraculous game. Amazing graphics (For 1993 at least), challenging pussles, incredibly frustratingly difficult levels that keep you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off enough so that you can't let the game win. Well, at least if you play on ''ULTRA VIOLENCE'' like I do. If you wanna have a walk in the park then the lower difficulties keep you entertained enough. The controls can feel a bit slow on the default settings but everything can be tweaked if you use the GZdoom sourceport. Doesn't matter which sourceport you use but for the love of god make sure you use one as the game is ugly and plays like ♥♥♥♥ in normal DOSbox mode. (It's just a program you download to up the resolution a bit, lots of other stuff and to get support for the incredibly popular mod ''Brutal DOOM''.) Even if you generally don't like fps games I truly recommend you try this piece of gaming history. Trust me, this is not anything like Call of Copy or Battlefield. So do yourself a favor and try the original game that set the world on fire. And if you don't, well, there's a dimensional shambler around that corner!

reviewText: Almost every FPS game released today owes their very existence to DOOM in some way or another. Most gamers have heard about DOOM. A legendary title that shaped the industry. Companies had to write up rules preventing it's workers from playing DOOM during work hours. It is estimated that DOOM was installed on over 10 million computers back in the day. Today it may look dated and old but the gameplay holds strong and the feeling you get playing it never gets old. This is another must play for any 90's FPS fan. Rip and tear indeed.

reviewText:
The Ultimate DOOM

DOOM is a must-own for any PC user. A classic FPS game defining its genre, go from point A to B, kill demons, pick up weapons, armor, and health. (Best formula for any popular video game) It runs on pretty much any electronic device, so there really is no excuse why you shouldn't play it.

Pros:
-Fun Theme
-Classic Soundtrack
-Great Level/Enemy Design
-Gory (For its time)
-Can easily use only a keyboard.

Cons:
-Graphics are not anything special (If that even matters for a game this old)
-Using a mouse for this game results in awkward movements and gameplay.
-This game's color scheme sometimes glitches in the first few boot-ups.

Verdict: 9/10 Satanic

reviewText: It's difficult to know where to begin when reviewing DOOM. For our generation, it's the equivalent of being handed the Bible and asked to give it a score out of ten..... The content isn't so much the important issue here, rather it's the legacy the game left behind.\n\nI don't think many people would argue that gaming (especially PC gaming) could be divided into Before DOOM" and "After DOOM". No
date: it wasn't the first to do many of the tricks we now take for granted. No
recommended: it wasn't the best FPS around. But.... the iPod wasn't the first portable music player and certainly wasn't the best
hoursPlayed: but it changed the way we listen to music forever. DOOM did the same thing for the FPS
voteText: and that's not an exaggeration.\n\nYou only have to look at the timeline of games development to see that it changed both the industry and people's attitudes. Suddenly
helpfulPercent: corporate networks were being clogged up with data from employees fragging each other when they should have been working. People at home were able to design their own levels and have others play them. The graphic violence drew criticism from various groups and DOOM was talked about in national media. Every games developer in the world was rushing their own FPS to market to try and cream off some of the publicity DOOM was generating. Some were successful (Duke Nukem 3D)
votesHelpful: some (Nitemare 3D?) less so.\n\nNo
votesTotal: it wasn't the first to do any of these things. But at the time it was nothing short of a phenomenon. There was barely a console around which didn't receive some version of DOOM at some point (Even the VIC-20 got one eventually thanks to homebrew).\n\nIs it the best game ever? No. But it's very important if you're even slightly interested in games
votesFunny: and you owe it to yourself to at least play it. The industry was never the same again after DOOM. It kick-started the interest in LAN gaming

reviewText: Back in the day when First-Person Shooters had not yet become the most oversaturated market in the gaming industry, Id Software created the legend that is Doom. A game so chock full of secrets, monsters, weapons, and good level design that many a young gamer's face was melted off by the sheer quality. Even today Doom holds up astonishingly well thanks to the aforementioned level designs, the likes of which have been sadly abandoned by many modern FPS games. It also has a sizable modding community that is still active.

reviewText: Doom is proof that while technological supremacy is fleeting, good game design is forever. Twenty-plus years after its release, it still stands tall as one of the greatest first person shooters ever made, an orgy of twitchy bloody death and destruction matched only by its own sequel. All the game needs to make you forget it came out in the early 90's is a fresh coat of paint, and all it takes is a few free downloads to cover that. GZDoom ports the game engine to run natively on windows, instead of requiring DOSbox, and gives the game a host of modern conveniences features like fully 3D environment rendering, texture filtering, and most importantly, proper mouse look. Brutal Doom, probably one of the best and most comprehensive mods ever made, fills out the package by overhauling the soundtrack, adding buckets and buckets of gore, and rebalancing the gameplay to be faster and more intense than ever.\n\nIf you're willing to take a few minutes to set it up properly, Doom is absolutely worth your time. It was great then, and thanks to twenty years of technical advancements and a somewhat overzealous fan community, it's even better now.

reviewText:
From soccer moms to Army Rangers, everyone's heard of Doom. Its name may well be synonymous with gaming controversy itself right beside Grand Theft Auto and E.T. It's one of the few 3D games that can say it's old enough to legally drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, and own a handgun in its home country at the time of writing. For a long time, I wanted to play the game that was so important it was deemed a national treasure of the United States. When I finally did, I didn't regret it for an instant.

It goes without saying; Doom is old. You can't crouch, you can't jump, you can't look up or down, and it's not even true 3D - 2.5D, as it was called, unable to stack rooms on top of one another. Pixelated monsters and environments straight out of 1993 look like an absolute mess at the ludicrous speeds the player is capable of and autoaim is a fact of life.

Despite how undeniably and understandably aged Doom is, it's still a fantastic game. It offers a healthy list of useful weapons with unique roles and a good variety of enemies that provide a fair challenge each. Valuable first-person shooter skills saw their rise to prominence in the bloodstained halls of the UAC labs and remain engaging twelve years later. Pacing that satisfies and yet leaves the player wanting for more contributes to an addicting game that gives the player control of how fast and how loose they want to fight their way through each demon-infested level.

Interesting usage of lighting, pleasing level design, detailed sprites and animations - few frames as they had - and a MIDI soundtrack so powerful you'd expect it to take up more than its 800KB in space all drive home Doom's finely aged experience. Even the stock sound effects that Doom relies upon are employed effectively and continue to make their presence heard in video games to this day.

It's no wonder that the first-person shooter genre had the title of Doom clone" when this classic was released. More than two decades after id Software put shooters on the map
date: Doom is still an absolute treat to play. To those who have yet to see what all the yelling and screaming is about
recommended: my recommendation is to take the plunge and start cooking with gas."
hoursPlayed: March 13, 2015
voteText: true
votesHelpful: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I'd like to think most gamers at least know what Doom is all about and why people like it, but I'll go ahead and lay it out.

This is my favorite shooter game in the world, and one of my favorite games period. It nails the logical progression of difficulty in terms of enemy placement and quantity as well as map layout. This game is so replayable -- it's actually among the first few games people had the idea of speedrunning. If you're not out for speed, then you can kick the difficulty up a notch or try and get every secret. Every weapon has a distinct application (save for the handgun) and feels satisfying to use. Fantastic gunplay.The Doom engine itself is divine, one of the best I can think of. The game is as challenging as you want it to be, anywhere from ♥♥♥♥ easy (I'm too young to die!) to brutally hard (Nightmare)

You can't ignore the music and graphics either. Some of the best, most appropriate game music and graphics that have aged incredibly well.

The atmosphere in Doom is absolutely flawless. Never does the game fail to make me feel like I've got a monstrous task ahead of me. Sometimes you'll be anxious to activate a switch that is so obviously a trap and you don't know if you can make it out alive, but you have to activate it anyway if you want to progess. At others, you'll channel the badass nature of your space marine avatar and let nobody out of your clutches. You're supposed to feel like this is a hell (heh) of a task to take on, but also that you're exactly the man for the job, and that's exactly the feeling Doom gives me.

With only select Bethesda ARPGs coming even close, Doom is probably the most modded game in the world. There are countless megaWADs, level packs, and gameplay-altering mods. And you can bet your sweet ♥♥♥ there's multiplayer mods available, each with level packs and gameplay mods of their own. Mods are coming out faster than you can probably play them, so don't worry about running out of content. With the base game and all these mods that have been coming out since the early '90s, anyone who gets a kick out of this game can easily get hundreds of hours of enjoyment out of it.

Basically, Doom is one of the most polished, most well-designed games on Earth (and Mars, and Hell) and I could play it forever.

10/10

reviewText:
Wait, what? Why are you reading some review for Doom?
It's Doom! You don't need a review for this all time classic!

Timeless soundtrack, epic gameplay, and level design that rivals modern game design in almost every regard.

My personal favorite shooter of all time, and even more fun with source ports (such as GZDoom) and mods (like Brutal Doom)!

Get it on Steam. Get it during a sale, if you're still skeptical. Get it on PSN, if you prefer that. Get it on your Xbox 360. Get it. It's the granddaddy of first person shooters, and it's aged like fine wine.

Just avoid the iOS port. It's actually really terrible.

DOOM is a pretty old game that I'm sure will bring back some fond memories to people who have been gaming for a while. Even if you never played it, DOOM is still a classic and its worth 5 bucks to check it out. I would like to note that this game currently will not run on Windows 8 (please update it to run on Windows 8), however it will run on Windows 7. The controls haven't aged very well, but its the price that has to be paid to experience DOOM.

Windows 7 rating: 8/10, its aged somewhat poorly in some aspects, but it has a certain charm.
Windows 8 rating: 1/10, it will not run, but on the brightside you get to look at a pretty awesome picture of DOOM Guy.

reviewText:
Where has this game been all my life? Honestly, I never expected it to be more fun than I thought it'd be.

Run around, shoot demons, collect guns, shoot demons, collect ammo, shoot demons, collect armor, shoot demons, collect powerups, shoot demons, collect keycards, open doors, push buttons, flip switches, find secrets, and shoot demons. So simple yet so elegant.

However, the control just doesn't hold up today. So the solution to that is to download a sourceport! There are quite a few out there, but I most reccommend GZDoom. You just need to first configure the controls and stuff and you'll be all set! It'll feel like a modern FPS in no time.

And then there's the mod Brutal Doom. More blood, more gore, prettier visual effects, new sprites, new functioning weapons, different customizations for the mod, just overall brilliant.

Buy the Doom Classic Complete pack. It'll be well worth it.

Rip and tear! Rip and tear their guts!
